author: {'steamid': '76561197970314107', 'num_games_owned': 2304, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1492296174}
review:
It helps for a game to have a clever hook, but it needs more than just that. Doing something outside the norm is great as long as that's expanded into a full game and not left to prop the whole thing up. Bardbarian has a cute premise but really doesn't go much further than that, seemingly expecting the one joke it's built around and a few cameos from other indie games to carry its terribly thin gameplay. That works for an hour or so, and then it just becomes a grinding slog without a punchline.

Bardbarian is the tale of Brad, mighty barbarian and defender of some dinky village with a giant, important, and otherwise unprotected crystal at its center. On this particular day Brad doesn't feel like vanquishing evil, instead opting to fashion a guitar out of an old battleaxe and jam out. Luckily for him, the villagers, and you, this inspires all manner of mercenaries to come to his aid, shredding monsters as he shreds and drawing power from his power chords.

In other words, you control Brad but you never attack on your own. You can call in one of three chosen units when you have enough chords (generated passively) which will follow you around and attack things within their range. At first you can only call three helpers at a time but through the game's gold-powered upgrade system you can raise that limit, as well as upgrade each mercenary. Brad can also spend chords to buff his team in various ways, and stun enemies when he reaches certain killstreaks.

Monsters come from three lanes on the right and trundle towards your crystal on the left, and if either that or Brad is destroyed, game over. Your minions also have health, so you'll need to weave your whole formation through the lazy projectiles your foes will lob. The game is broken into four chapters of five lengthy waves each, with a boss on the fifth wave. Everything drops gold for you to buy upgrades with between runs; once you start playing you're locked into what you have until you win or die.

This is where the game starts to wear thin, because death is going to be stopping you pretty regularly. There's a significant jump in difficulty between chapters, mainly because of enemies getting huge health and damage boosts. Little critters you could kill in 3 arrows suddenly take 12. It feels like the power curve of a mobile game, forcing you to grind on your current level before unlocking enough upgrades to stand a chance at the next. That's exactly what I did, too, playing chapter 1 until I had the archer units fully upgraded, along with a larger squad size and higher base levels and other stuff. Chapter 2 was still a challenge but I pulled it off, and then Chapter 3 immediately kicked me in the balls until I died.

Ultimately the upgrade system is going to be your main focus, and it isn't even that interesting to begin with. Unit upgrades just make them generally beefier but the early units don't hold a candle to the later ones you unlock, so you can waste gold on guys that can't carry you to the finish line. There's a 2x drops unlock that's basically mandatory but terribly expensive, and the squad size upgrade is obviously the most important but scales ludicrously in cost. It's going to take a lot of grinding the same waves over and over, which will exacerbate how slow and long they tend to be, and how little you actually need to do besides dodging bullets.

Even the actual combat is underwhelming, with slow projectiles and weak sound effects for all of them. You get virtually no feedback on damage, either, with a hit doing a sliver of health and a hit one-shotting you looking and sounding exactly the same. There's very little variety in enemy behavior as well, and that extends even to the bosses. And forget about the survival and escape modes, because they dumb down the gameplay even further. Like I said, it's a cute concept to hang a game on but Bardbarian is paper-thin, offering little in the way of content or challenge to keep you rocking along.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

author: {'steamid': '76561198147485569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1491505816}
review:
[b][h1]Bardbarian[/h1][/b]

Estimated gameplay hours: 6-7-10.

[b][u]Game Genre:[/u][/b] 2D Mixed Strategy-Tower Def with RPG elements.
This game may look like one of those cheap internet / app games but it is very enjoyable to play.

[b][u]Gameplay:[/u][/b] Your goal is to defend the town by killing the enemies round after round, but what makes it good is the RPG aspect.
You have 20 rounds, 4 bosses & more than 15 units & hero/town upgrades that would help you sucessfully survive each round.

If you're not getting bored from random games very fast and have an open mind for this type of game, you will find it fun to play therefore, I recommend it.

[b]Overall Score: 8/10[/b]

[b]*Game Tips*[/b]
[i]-- Units --[/i] I used Archer & Mage at lower rounds and few Wizards + 2 Tank & 1 Shaman at higher rounds, it works well.
(Necromancer at mid rounds is also recommended).
[i]-- Hero Skills --[/i] 'Golden Axe' first, Damage,Speed,Party upgrade(more units) & Note Regeneration+Distance between units.
[i]-- Town Upgrades -- [/i] 'Friends', Pet skill is a must, Magic castle (for magic units XP Level) & 'Town Drunk' is also nice.

[i]* Skip it.[/i]
[i]** Not Recommended.[/i]
[h1][i][b]*** Give It A Try.[/b][/i][/h1]
[h1][i][b]**** Recommended On Sale.[/b][/i][/h1]
[i]****** Recommended On Full Price.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198041150422', 'num_games_owned': 568, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1488851071}
review: Unit upgrades affect your progress in the game.   Might be fun for a challenge to try and run through it using a new game save with as much stuff maxed out before starting day 1 since unlocked units don't show up between waves again after you have unlocked them.  Ignore the developer's description, whatever nonsense that is.  Stop enemies from reaching the left side via controlling a large hitbox of grouped units.  Music would be good if there was more than one song the entire game.  Beat it using necromancer to provide a wall, rune knight for attack, and shaman to slow mobs down.  Sadly, more necros don't result in more zombies and you're limited to six.  The final boss fight was a little unintuitiive at first.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973785927', 'num_games_owned': 274, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 815, 'last_played': 1485900243}
review:
I have to say, I had a blast with this game.  It‚Äôs essentially a type of DOTA/tower defense game.  Your role is to summon and buff an NPC party that follows you automatically performs its roll.  Attackers target and attack enemies in range, healers heal when you stop walking, defenders deflect ranged enemy attacks when they are struck and so on.  You earn gold as you play which you spend after you die to improve the town, units, buffs and other aspects of the game.  The music is pretty great too, it was stuck in my head for days.  There are 3 gameplay modes, which lets you switch things up a bit, as well as a harder dificulty to select when you create a new game file.

My list of complaints is pretty short.  Some of the units felt pretty underwhelming, and if you pick a good group you are essentially unbeatable, which can hurt replayability.  Since you only get one town and never go anywhere else there isn‚Äôt much opportunity for the game to present situations where using specific units or combinations is very impactful.  There isn‚Äôt much variety of enemies, which isn‚Äôt a big deal, but I think is worth noting.

I would love to see more locations added in an update, but as is it is still a great little game I would recommend picking up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008870686', 'num_games_owned': 1268, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1483759924}
review:
Hey this is a fun game.  You control a bard who has a group of warriors wizards etc. that you can lead into battle to fight off waves of enemies.  The waves are like what you'd find in a tower defense game, and you pick and choose your crew that follow you around on the battlefield, attacking enemies that are near.  The strategy comes in who you add to your party, and taking money earned in rounds to buy upgrades to you, your recruits and the town you are defending.

Its a good simple game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009528477', 'num_games_owned': 1986, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1484668534}
review:
If you enjoy a good (?) grindfest just to play a tower defense game, in which your only task is to run around dodging bullets, then this is what you want to buy.
To me it felt more like a chore. There is no real motivation, your whole aspiration is basically trying to amass enough gold to buy all the upgrades and then breeze through the game. Problem is, that you don't really have to invest much effort gameplay wise and even if you do, the rewards are just more gold and some unlockable characters, which might or might not have a use to your playing style and whose upgrades you have to pay for with that good old gold again. The whole "grind gold" aspect really shows that this was/is a mobile game and the model might work there with their f2p games, but on a PC game I expect a bit more meat on the bone.

Other than that it can be an alright 10 minute time waster but nothing you'd wanna play for a longer time. You're basically that barbarian guy, who's tired of grinding for xp so he decided to now grind for gold, which shows us why barbarians have such a low intelligence stat in every rpg ever. To fulfill that tedious task, you're equipped with an axe that is used as a guitar and you're able to summon some followers (who actually do the fighting for you and follow you in a weird snake-like fashion) and to play three different buffs (speed, dmg, def). Your job is to protect the core from baddies, there's a bossfight every 5 or so stages (20 stages in total iirc) and that's that. You are also only able to upgrade your things once you die, so be prepared to start over quite a few times. Sounds thrilling ?

author: {'steamid': '76561198055977195', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1484526067}
review:
Bardbarian
About The Game: Bardbarian is a mix between a side scroller hack n'slash, a bullet hell, and a tower defence game. You play as Brad the barbarian, turned bard. It is still your job to defend the town from goblin and demon hordes. This time you let your groupies do all the hard work as you riff and jam about the place. Chose 3 from up to 18 different groupies, along with 16 upgrades between you and the town. After death you get your collected gold to make upgrades, and then try again to beat your record.

Pantsu's Rating (out of 5)
Graphics: 3.5 Nothing epic but still clean and not really glitchy. Although i find monsters hiding under the bottom HUD.
Playability: 4 WSDA movement with changeable hotkeys for summons and solos make the controls enjoyable.
Fun: 3.5 This game is pretty fun but after a while it gets tedious keeping your groupies from eating bullets.
Sound: 4 Metal jams and solo riffs entertain the ears. The background music is upbeat and keeps the action flowing.
Replay Value: 3 There are extra modes including an insane mode, Halloween mode, survival mode, and an escape mode. As for the main game, once you fully upgrade everything there isn't much left to do.
Final Score: 3.5
Final Thought: At $7.99 it is worth waiting for a sale but on a good note, it is offered in a bundle with another Treefortress game, Jump Jet Rex, and soundtrack for $14.99.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967626206', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1481782368}
review:
I just can't recommend this game, even though that puts me in a small minority. I play a lot of casual, quick games. They key thing is they need to entertain me quickly, easily and just have short bursts of fun. 

I started this game, and realised I was just... well... bored...

Take games like Guild of Dungeoneering, The Binding of Isaac. Diehard Dungeon, One Finger Death Punch or a lot of other awesome casual games. They are fun, quickly. 

This honestly wasn't. I was just running around dodging while my summons fire. If I compare it to The Binding of Isaac, which is also broadly about running around dodging and shooting, this just isn't in the same league. I know they are different, but ultimately, one is fun, the other just isn't. Sorry, but casual shouldn't equal mundane. The team have tried. And it's a polished game (other than sloppy text not lining up with the dialogue boxes). But it's just plain boring unfortunately :(

review:
Croisement entre tower d√©fense, beat'em all tellement les "balles" fusent, et pseudo-RPG avec progression des unit√©s, du village et du h√©ros, Bardbarian est rafra√Æchissant et tout en fran√ßais. Seul d√©faut, avec une seule m√©lodie r√©p√©t√©e √† l'infini, Assurancetourix n'a rien √† craindre. Brad, lui aussi on finit par le bailloner. Non, franchement, l√†, les d√©veloppeurs auraient pu nous proposer quelques pistes endiabl√©es suppl√©mentaires.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048865581', 'num_games_owned': 2546, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 829, 'last_played': 1479051421}
review:
Bardbarian is a cute casual wave survival game.

The story doesn't exist, so check that off.
The graphics look cartoony and nice. It's pleasing to the eye for sure. 
It runs well. The achievements are easy to get and the soundtrack is really good. After writing this review, I'll find a way to get it. 
You can play the game on either normal or hardcore, but all achievement hunters should want to play on hardcore. 
After that you have the main survival mode, runner mode and a Day 2 mode that unlocks after the game's been beaten. It's all good and fun. It works and that's what matters.

Overall, I'd recommend this game if you want a casual experience.
5/10

(All games start off at a 5/10 and the grade raises and lowers for every pro and con present)

author: {'steamid': '76561197992208010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1478257447}
review:
I have played a significant amount of this game. It's good. Much better than the closest title I can think of in terms of mood and gameplay, that being plants vs zombies - and unlike that title, it represents a challenge.
The ending is a little weak, you'd think they'd put in at least as much effort as they put into the intro (which wasn't much).
But it's an enjoyable game.

Think tower defense meets bullet hell meets Dungeon Siege, and you're kind of close. Whimsical.
Only beef is with the difficulty level, which curves rather drastically.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997355440', 'num_games_owned': 3002, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 485, 'last_played': 1476795860}
review:
En general, un juego peque√±o muy bien hecho. Por momentos, me recuerda al Plants vs. Zombies original, en el sentido de que est√° dise√±ado para ser compacto y elegante, sin profundidad artificial de montones de opciones o actualizaciones de funcionalidad ininteligible y con el suficiente sentido del humor para que, ah√≠ donde pueda faltar motivaci√≥n para continuar por la pr√°cticamente nula historia o la profundidad limitada, alcance para volver a intentarlo. La progresi√≥n es constante y regularmente cualquier ronda alcanza para adquirir una mejora m√°s, que adem√°s, al estar limitadas a cinco o tres en cada apartado, la diferencia entre niveles es apreciable. No como, digamos, en esos juegos donde hay 10 o 20 niveles y la diferencia entre el nivel 14 y el 15 es imperceptible.

Como puntos negativos, aunque estas son m√°s obsesiones m√≠as: no puede bajarse el volumen de la m√∫sica. Apagada o prendida, solamente. Y aborrezco cuando los personajes de un juego son conscientes de estar en un juego y digan cosas como ¬´cansado de reunir XP, se fue a su casa¬ª y similares. Cosa m√°s triste no hay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138440173', 'num_games_owned': 1124, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 644, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 644, 'last_played': 1472042974}
review:
[h1][b]Bardbarian ist ein RPG Tower-Defense von TreeFortress Games[/b][/h1]

In Bardbarian spielt der Spieler einen barbarischen Barden, der sein Dorf mit Hilfe seiner zauberhaften Metalkr√§fte besch√ºtzt.

[h1]Hauptmen√º:[/h1]

Im Hauptmen√º wird der Spieler vom blonden Barden, einigen seiner Kumpane und ein paar fiesen Gegnern begr√º√üt.
Dieses Hauptmen√º kann in zwei verschiedenen Modi ausgef√ºhrt werden. Normal und Halloween.

Das Hauptmen√º ist √ºbersichtlich, es gibt vier w√§hlbare Reiter: Settings, Play, Credits, Exit.

Das Hauptmen√º ist interaktiv, wenn die Maus sich bewegt, bewegt sich auch der Hintergrund. Es gibt sogar etwas zu entdecken, dies sollte der Spieler jedoch selbst herausfinden.


[h1]Spielmodi:[/h1]

Es gibt 2 Hauptmodi: [b]Normal[/b] und [b]Nightmare[/b], diese unterscheiden sich in ihrer Schwierigkeit.
In diesen Hauptmodi besch√ºtzt der Spieler sein Dorf, wertet dieses auf und kauft n√ºtzliche Dinge.
Es gibt 20 Wellen, alle f√ºnf Wellen erscheinen ein oder mehrere Bossgegner.


In diesen Spielmodi befinden sich noch Minispiele.

[b]"Unendlich":[/b] Hier l√§uft der Spieler durch einen endlosen Level und versucht allem Unangenehmen auszuweichen.

[b]"√úberleben":[/b] Der Spieler ist in einem Level mit begrenztem Platz und versucht, so lange wie m√∂glich, zu √ºberleben. Es spawnen immer mehr Gegner. Manchmal spawnen auch Kumpane, Bacon (heilt 25% leben) und Noten (n√∂tig, um Zauber zu wirken) mit deren Hilfe das √úberleben gesichert werden soll.

[b]"Day 2":[/b] Day 2 ist ein freischaltbarer Modus, in welchem die Wellen vom Hauptspiel weitergehen.


[h1]Schwierigkeit:[/h1]

Die Schwierigkeit des Spiels variiert nur leicht zwischen "Normal" und "Nightmare", ausschlaggebend ist hier eher, wie weit man im Spiel fortgeschritten ist und wie viele Kumpane man bereits freigeschalten hat.


[h1]Grafik:[/h1]

Bardbarian hat eine lustige Comic-Grafik, welche zum Spiel passt und die Atmosph√§re unterst√ºtzt.


[h1]Musik:[/h1]

In Bardbarian spielt im Hintergrund ausschlie√ülich Alternative Rock und Metal, was zu unserem harten Barden sehr gut passt.
Die wenigen Musikst√ºcke sind sehr gut gemacht und f√ºr jeden Metal-Fan ein Ohrenschmaus.


[h1]Spielspa√ü:[/h1]

Bardbarian macht nicht nur zwischendurch Mal kurz Spa√ü, es ist auch f√ºr l√§ngere Spielsessions geeignet und macht sogar ein wenig s√ºchtig, wenn man, wie ich, immer in der letzten Welle abkratzt *hust*.


[h1]Spielzeit:[/h1]

Pers√∂nlich habe ich, zum Zeitpunkt dieses Reviews, 10,7 Stunden gebraucht, um alle Errungenschaften zu erhalten. Ein durchschnittlicher Spieler d√ºrfte zwischen 5 und 7 Stunden brauchen. 
Dadurch h√§lt sich die Spielzeit in Grenzen.

[h1]Preis/Leistung:[/h1]

8‚Ç¨ sind f√ºr die meisten Tower-Defense Spiele eine Stangen Geld. Aber durch die gro√üe Menge an Content, Spielspa√ü und verdammt gut gemachte Grafik und Musik, lohnt es sich, Bardbarian zu kaufen.


[h1] Errungenschaften:[/h1]

Es gibt 22 Errungenschaften, von denen die meisten innerhalb k√ºrzester Zeit erreicht werden k√∂nnen, die letzten Errungenschaften k√∂nnen, wenn man so bl√∂d ist, wie ich, einige Zeit auf sich warten. Daf√ºr kann man dann l√§nger spielen.


[h1]Hauptmen√º: 9/10[/h1]
[h1]Spielmodi: 10/10[/h1]
[h1]Schwierigkeit: 7/10[/h1]
[h1]Grafik: 8/10[/h1]
[h1]Musik: 8/10[/h1]
[h1]Spielspa√ü: 10/10[/h1]
[h1]Spielzeit: 6/10[/h1]
[h1]Preis/Leistung: 9/10[/h1]

[h1][b]Gesamtpunktzahl: 8/10[/b][/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198037854231', 'num_games_owned': 228, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 821, 'last_played': 1659140467}
review:
Apesar de parecer simples como a maioria de jogos do estilo "Tower Defense", Bardbarian tem seu diferencial.

- √â necess√°rio ter uma boa mobilidade para desviar das habilidades inimigas e tbm controlar o range de atk e habilidades de sua party, caracter√≠stica pouco encontrada em "TDs" e mais em jogos Arcade.
-Vc n√£o ataca, apenas sua party (exceto 1 healer e 1 tank que reflete proj√©teis), mas usufl√∫i de 4 "Solos"(buffs) com efeitos caracter√≠scos de acordo com a necessidade, e summona at√© 4 diferentes unidades pra te ajudar (somando at√© 9 simult√¢neas).
-Existem in√∫meras combina√ß√µes de party possibilitando v√°rias estrat√©gias diferentes, o que deixa o jogo menos enjoativo e mais desafiador.
-Vc pode upar sua vila (base), aumentando a vida do "Nexus"(q vc deve proteger), 2 torres auxiliares pr√≥ximas do "Nexus", pode tbm upar as lojas e NPCs de sua vila pra te ajudarem com comida (cura), dinheiro e CC (slow). 
-Pode aprimorar seu personagem (Vida, mobilidade, ganho de gold, buffs, distanciamento da party, quantidade m√°xima da party at√© 9, etc.)
-Pode desbloquear e aprimorar cada personagem da sua party, cada um com suas caracter√≠sticas e habilidades.
-N√£o √© um jogo longo, d√° pra zerar sem antes enjoar, tanto que vc vai querer fazer as conquistas conforme vai evoluindo.
-Depois de matar os 4 chefes das 20 fases √© liberado lvls 21+ os quais acredito eu que n√£o tenha fim, pois s√£o extremamente dif√≠ceis conforme vai passando de fase, ainda mais se for jogar no modo insano.
-Tem tbm o modo Survival e Escape.
-Trilha sonora empolgante que deixa a jogatina mais fren√©tica e n√£o te deixa perder o ritmo.

Em promo√ß√£o vale a pena comprar o jogo, pois √© um √≥timo passatempo pra qdo quer jogar algo diferente pra distrair a cabe√ßa e se divertir. Minha filha adorou me ver jogando! Rsrsrsrsrsrsrsrs

Eu particulamente recomendo!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010267364', 'num_games_owned': 1213, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1468378909}
review:
Repetition in video games can be draining sometimes. There's only so many times you can jump on things, slash them, shoot them, right? And if that's the case for you the player, what must it be like for the characters actually doing the work? Bardbarian's a game that explores that a bit.

You play as Brad, a barbarian mercenary working to defend a nameless town and its giant magic crystal, which does...probably something important, since every monster in the area wants it smashed, although they never get around to saying what. Trouble is, Brad is having a bit of a mid-life crisis: surely there must be more to life than constant killing? The answer to that he finds is embracing his artistic side in the form of music, and helping other people kill things!

Bardbarian takes place in the town for the whole of the game, as twenty waves assault the crystal over the course of a single day. These make up four sections, with five levels each and a boss at the end. To combat them, Brad has to jam on his guitar and summon allies from out of the local barracks and wizard college; they move in to close formation around him, not unlike Tiny Guardians. This game is action-based, however, and you'll be moving back and forth to let your allies shoot down monsters with either the arrow keys, WADS, the mouse or a controller. You start off with a simple archer-wizard-fighter combo, but as you unlock units by passing waves you'll find more interesting ones, like a necromancer who curses enemies, and resurrects them as a zombie minion if they're killed under the effects of it. There are also some indie cameos from Octodad, a Super Meat Boy/Isaac tag team, and Shellrazer, who's from a mobile tower defense that isn't on Steam.

If twenty waves sounds a bit short to you, well, it kind of is. The length mostly comes from you kind of having to go back and upgrade your allies, Brad himself, and the town with the gold you get from killing enemies; even if you're very good at dodging they'll simply get too spongey. After every boss you'll have the option of starting at the next area whenever you do, so you won't have to start at the beginning every time. There are also upgrades to make gathering gold easier, such as the Pet, who will grab it from dead enemies so you don't have to.

Even with upgrades, though, the game can be quite tricky, and I wouldn't necessarily recommend it to people without experience in shooters. Most enemies have some sort of projectile attack, and it isn't long before it a minor bullet hell, with you weaving in and out to protect your squishier allies and Brad himself. You'll need to be proactive when dealing with enemies, too, as letting even a couple goblins get up to the crystal can lead to quite a bit of damage. Naturally, it's also a game over if you die yourself. And if you really want a challenge, there's an even harder difficulty you can pick right from the start.

It took me about nine hours to beat the game, although it might take a bit longer for someone not as good at action games. There are two optional modes in addition to it; a challenge mode where you try to survive against an endless horde of enemies, and a sort of runner minigame where you try to avoid obstacles. They can both give gold, but it still felt like the main campaign was the most efficient method of doing that, and it doesn't feel like they'd extend the playtime very much.

Bardbarian is definitely a good game if you can put up with some grinding, although I'm not certain I would buy it at full price. It's been on sale a bunch though, and can be found in one of the permanent bundles on BundleStars. It's a decent game with some charm for in-between larger ones, I'd say.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083589505', 'num_games_owned': 578, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 496, 'last_played': 1468960384}
review:
Juego bastante divertido. No tiene muchas horas de juego, ni demasiada rejugabilidad en mi opini√≥n, pero es un concepto divertido, y tiene una buena dificultad.

En resumen, te mueves por el mapa evitando que los enemigos lleguen al otro lado, como un Tower Defense. Sin embargo, t√∫ no atacas. Invocas "seguidores" que se mueven contigo y atacan ellos autom√°ticamente a los enemigos. Se trata de combinar los tipos de seguidores, y esquivar proyectiles para que los enemigos no los maten (ni te maten a ti).

author: {'steamid': '76561198035560545', 'num_games_owned': 3970, 'num_reviews': 224, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 393, 'last_played': 1429425904}
review:
Supposedly the protagonist Brad got tired of the grind for XP and decided to retire to be a bard, but this game is still nothing but grind. 

Brad doesn‚Äôt directly attack enemies, but instead plays music to summon members of his party that are selected before the game starts. Half of the game is spending coins to upgrade all kinds of passives for the town, units and Brad himself, but the single upgrade paths are all standard. The player gets some sense of strategy by picking which units to include in their party, which is kind of like selecting what towers to build in a TD game, except being mobile takes away figuring out the puzzle of a good maze or what tower combinations are most efficient for an area. The other part of the game is spent as Brad running around while his party auto attacks enemies. After a while the game kind of feels like it plays itself for the most part.  It never seemed like I got better at fighting the same handful of enemies over and over again while listening to the same melody, in the same environment.
 
I bought in for the promise of more content, mainly co-op, and for the crossover characters. The crossover novelty was cool, but wore off, and the promised content has yet to come. Maybe I would have enjoyed it more with co-op, but overall it was a lukewarm experience. 

Bardbarian is functional and can be fun for a while, but it‚Äôs not really that engaging.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987658658', 'num_games_owned': 1431, 'num_reviews': 341, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1590577838}
review:
https://youtu.be/VpGlwCFMqkE

Bardbarian, au del√† de son nom rigolol est un Tower defense qui ne paye pas de mine mais qui est plutot sympathique. Vous dirigez un barbare qui doit d√©fendre le centre ville d'attaques d'ennemis divers.
Ok, le barbare, il d√©fonce tout et il coupe des t√™tes, c'est √ßa hein? 
En fait non, il a une guitarre qui lui sert √† appeller des alli√©s qui vont s'occuper des ennemis √† se place. Il peut √©galement donner des buffs d'attaque, de d√©fense et de vitesse mais il n'attaque pas.

Quelle est la particularit√© du jeu alors? H√© bien, comme le barbare n'attaque pas mais que les alli√©s suivent le barbare, il faut approcher le barbare suffisament pr√®s des ennemis pour que les alli√©s les d√©foncent. Le probl√®me, c'est que, du coup, vous √™tes maxi-expos√© aux attaques adverses et susceptible de conna√Ætre un sort funeste. Toute la subtilit√© vient donc du fait de bien savoir bouger.

Les alli√©s, le h√©ros et la ville peuvent √™tre am√©lior√©s avec l'or r√©cup√©r√©.
Le contenu est plutot limit√© : 20 vagues, un mode infini et un mode fuite. Toutes les 5 vagues, vous avez un nouveau chapitre duquel vous pouvez d√©marer. Les vagues sont cependant difficiles et le d√©fi de faire les 20 vagues d'une traite promet de ne pas √™tre ais√©.

Pour 2 ‚Ç¨, prix de mon achat, √ßa le vaut.
JE regrette quand m√™me: les graphismes limit√©s, l'absence d'un sc√©nar et le trailer steam pas √† jour.
Si vous √™tes un malade du TD comme moi, c'est bien, mais √ßa ne convertira pas les frileux ou les n√©ophytes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136763678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 933, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 546, 'last_played': 1468549099}
review:
A fun little tower defense game with an interesting premise but not worth the $8 asking price. Buy it when it's on sale for 75% off like I did and you won't feel bad at all. I mean, it's pretty much a slightly more polished Kongregate game and honestly, there are free Kongregate games that are actually more in-depth and flat out more fun to play. I can't write the game off completely because I did get 5 hours worth of play out of it. But honestly it was more because I truly wanted to like the game more than I did because it is sort of an interesting take on tower defense style games and it is fun for a while as you progress and unlock new characters and perks.

My biggest gripe with the game is the fact that it's called Bardbarian and the entire premise is based around you controlling the Bard (essentially a pied-piper type character) and everything about the game revolves around music and, well, being a bard. However, the soundtrack is so depressingly lacking, it basically becomes little more than background hum if you play it for any real length of time. Sadly, the ONE song that is the entire soundtrack is actually quite decent. But it's one freaking song. And not even really a complete song but a riff on a loop. I honestly feel that if they were more inventive with the soundtrack and how it played into the game, the $8 asking price would not only have been reasonable, but it would have been a deal. IMO, games like this live and die by their soundtrack and sadly this game died with it's.

The overall gameplay is extremely satisfactory for a casual tower defense, the key word here being casual. I mean, you don't aim, you don't shoot anything, there is no placement of towers, you basically weave your band of hand-chosen characters, each with their pros and cons, through waves of increasingly difficult levels. That is, once you start progressing and unlocking more characters with increasingly different character traits. This may sound like an extreme bore but it really is balanced when it comes to difficulty and satisfaction as you unlock new characters and/or perks. Sure, you're only essentially bobbing and weaving and leading your charges into battle but, it's really not as easy as it sounds and there is a real emphasis on choosing your characters and perks wisely.

I'm giving this a recommend overall but at a warning that I honestly don't think it's worth the retail price. Put it on your wishlist and catch it on sale. I paid $1.99 during the Summer Sale and feel like I certainly got my money's worth for that price. I certainly don't mind supporting indie devs, especially when they release truly enjoyable content, but at some point, I have to ask myself if the price is worth the product when there are so many similar titles out there that you can play 100% free.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041949592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 605, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1467303966}
review:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a Tower defence   game.


[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]

You can play this game Fullscreen or windowed mode.
There are some other Languages.
You are able to change your controls on the keyboard.
You can only turn off the Sound and music. There is no Volume bar.
You can play this game with a xbox controller.

[h1]About the game.[/h1]

You are playing with a barbarian that is only able to move around. He can't attack enemies by hisself but he is able to call his friends or units. You are walking around and the units are following you, You can pick up enemy gold if they has been killed and you need to dodge their attacks to avoid damage. Most of the units are surrounding around you but you and them can still take damage. If one of your units has been destroyed, they will drop some of the musical notes. Musical notes are needed to call units. You will get musical notes overtime or sometimes from enemy drops. You can spend gold to upgrade your hero, Units or even town supplies. You are somewhat dependant on your units, because the only thing that you are able to do is walking around. Your units will upgrade themself during waves but these are only temporary. There is a small map on the top, where you can see enemy movement. There are 2 other game modes. Called survival and escape. If playing Escape, you will have 1 health and you run as much as you can on the right side of the screen. Avoiding enemy bullets and grabbing gold on your way. 

There is a ingame tutorial.
Upgrade Shop (Units/Hero/Town).
Has small map on the top.
Has 2 different game modes. (Survival mode and escape)
Units upgrade themself during waves.
You can Pause during waves.
Game progression feels slow. (upgrading and clearing waves).
VERY Dependant on ur units and your units are a bit MEH in term of play.
Super Grinding.
Game Goes too slow and makes it Semi-Boring

[h1]Other things.[/h1]

Some Easter eggs. Like Characters from different games.
Playing Challenges could spoil some locked units or enemies, as you can use and see them.

-------------------

I Give this game a 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198067227433', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1474649673}
review:
Short: Flash game like. Lot of farming. Fun for some time. Wait for sale.

This game is basically a flash game, but a good one. You destroy waves of incoming enemies before they reach the town crystal (deliberate silliness). You cannot attack monsters directly, though: you have to chant out a small band of warriors which will follow you closely. The goal is to dodge projectiles, while coming close enough the enemies so that your soldiers can kill them. Which means: you basically only have to move. Simplistic, but it proves efficiently entertaining.

Of course, as it has a flash game mechanics, you won't be able to go very far on your first run, but you win money with which you can upgrade yourself and your followers (as well as diverse features). Everything is quite basic, so do not expect much. It is fun, though, even if you have to repeat endlessly the same few waves. There is some diversity among the monsters, and a good choice of different followers. Developers have surely been imaginative on that side. 

It gets boring after a few hours of gameplay, alas. Plus, the additional modes (survival and run) are most boring. In the survival mode, you can not do anything but dodge every foes for entire long minutes. Running is slow and devoid of any interest. Only the main game mode is worth playing; the other two are for achievements only. 

Do not spend more than 3 euros/dollars in it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038862043', 'num_games_owned': 731, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1624311441}

author: {'steamid': '76561198014296958', 'num_games_owned': 2476, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 615, 'last_played': 1451830279}
review:
Extremely fun game and several hours of playtime guaranteed. 
The graphics are a bit like Castle Crashers and the game mechanics feel similar as well. I played this game from start to finish with my xbox 360 controller and it worked flawless with the game. 

The replay value is 'meh' since you can unlock more characters to assist you and you can try new tactics to finish the game faster, but nothing you'd want to play weeks on end. There's also the challenge levels, which are pretty alright, but the most fun for me was the actual campaign.

If the current pricetag of 8 euro is too steep for you, I would definitely recommend getting it during a sale.

review:
Bardbarian √© um game indie lan√ßado no ano de 2014 pela TreeFortress Games que traz a mistura dos g√™neros aventura, a√ß√£o, tower defense e estrat√©gia. O game acontece em um ambiente 2D e voc√™ comanda uma b√°rbaro bardo que n√£o ataca apenas faz composi√ß√µes musicais afim de salvar sua cidade do ataque compulsivo de orcs.

O enredo √© simples, uma cidade possui uma fonte inesgot√°vel de energia originada de um cristal poderoso e os orcs a fim de derrotar e tomar conta do reino, pois querem destruir esse cristal. A partir da√≠ o bardo b√°rbaro √© escalado para a miss√£o de atrav√©s de suas can√ß√µes, comandar as tropas e evitar a invas√£o orc.

O jogo possui uma jogabilidade extremamente simples, voc√™ utiliza-se de notas musicais para criar suas unidades e deve movimentar-se pr√≥ximo aos orcs para que elas ataquem, o jogo √© bem fren√©tico e muito r√°pido, o segredo dele √© movimentar-se a todo o momento, a cada horda de orcs superadas voc√™ adquire recompensas em ouro que por sua vez ser√£o utilizados para comprar melhorias para voc√™, suas tropas e sua cidade al√©m de novos armamentos e novos tipos de unidades. Ap√≥s algum tempo o jogo torna-se muito repetitivo, principalmente que quando voc√™ morre √© obrigado a recome√ßar todas as hordas.

Para compor a trilha sonora notamos a forte influ√™ncia do rock tanto na m√∫sica que acompanha o momento da batalha quanto os solos de invoca√ß√£o de unidades, o grande problema aqui √© a repetitividade da m√∫sica, pois n√£o s√£o muitas que embalam a aventura.

Os gr√°ficos s√£o bem desenhados e bem coloridos, s√£o feitos em 2D mais n√£o apresentam uma p√©ssima qualidade, as unidades s√£o bem representadas e alguns detalhes de movimenta√ß√£o e ataque s√£o bem feitos, como o jogo √© indie acredito que n√£o houve um grande investimento, por√©m no quesito gr√°fico o game n√£o deixa a desejar.

Bardbarian √© um indie casual, uma boa pedida para algumas horas de distra√ß√£o, o game √© bastante desafiador mais a falta de conte√∫do diferenciado n√£o permite que o game tenha uma grande vida √∫til. O game √© divertido e vale a pena conferir em uma promo√ß√£o, pois pode ser um bom nome para ser colocado em pr√°tica naquela jogatina r√°pida.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967817775', 'num_games_owned': 2072, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 578, 'last_played': 1398246108}
review: As someone who buys a lot of game bundles I tend to jump into numerous indie titles site unseen, something that usually ends poorly. Bardbarian however was a pleasant surprise, a game that takes two genres I'm usually lukewarm on (tower defense and shumps) and manges to combine them in a way that I found super addictive. It does get a bit grindy towards the end, but I found the mechanics entertaining enough in their own right that I never felt too bored. The charming art-style was a big plus as well. An easy reccomendation for anyone looking for something to tackle in bite-size chunks (it's a great 15 minute break game) and for the achivement hunters out there, they're a pretty easy 100%.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999920602', 'num_games_owned': 701, 'num_reviews': 623, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1547334927}
review: This is a 2D defense game where you hire minions to follow you around and kill things on your behalf. I completed it in one sitting; it‚Äôs got great animations, some original mechanics and nice humour. The upgrades system works well & the difficulty curve is spot on - except for perhaps the last boss which took inordinately longer than everything else. Once I‚Äôd maxed out my wizards it was just a case of not getting one-shot by the Beholders for the last 3 waves of the game. Not sure how I would have completed it without their sniper knockback! Only other criticism is the music; it‚Äôs good - but only one 30 second clip on a loop got old really quickly considering the game is about 5 hours long.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991112921', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1465675215}
review: This game is actually pretty fun and fairly unique. It combines bullet hell, tower defense, and RPG elements in a pretty compelling way. So why the thumbs down, you ask? Well, this version of the game is priced higher than it should be. First off, the claim of "Steam exclusive" characters in this version is completely false. Don't believe me? Download the FREE version on Google Play or the App Store and see for yourself. The only item that costs money in the free (and virtually identical) version is the golden axe, which is obtained with in game currency in this version but costs only $3 in the free tablet/smartphone version. This game is normally priced at $8 and thus, I cannot recommend it unless you get it on sale (for controller support, I suppose). However, tablet controls are not bad and you can even play it on an emulator if you don't have a tablet. So, skip this version unless you happen to see it for at least 50% off.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026806776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 302, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1460432020}
review:
[i]Bardbarian[/i] is an evade-'em-up game.  You play an overmuscled Conan figure who has decided that he's sick of hacking foes to death and only wants to play music, which might be a more noble attitude if his village wasn't presently under siege by the usual forces of darkness.  Thankfully, your music (plus money, earned by killing enemies) can inspire less-squeamish types to follow you around and do the dirty work for you.  Strategy revolves around getting close enough to enemies for your followers to attack them, but still avoiding enemy fire, and recruiting and upgrading an effective mix of followers.

This game doesn't have much depth, it isn't all that compelling, and probably won't hold your interest very long, but it's just different enough from typical games to make it a good short-term casual game.  If your expectations are modest, it will meet them -- that's about all it's fair to ask from a casual game like this.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198277011659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 624, 'last_played': 1457465237}
review: This game was a positive surprise for me. The game is about a former barbarian who was sick of fighting with weapons and decided to turn his axe into a lute. With his lute he summons different warriors by his side to attacktheir enemies. The game is a basically a tower defense game but you can only place towers next to your character, and then you run around the field protecting the village crystal. It's a common concept with it's on twist, and the music is really good. Charming graphics and nice controls makes this a fine game. You also have 2 other game modes except the story. Survival which is one big screen, lots of enemies, and you running in circles to survive. Then we have Escape mode, which is screen scrolling mode, where you simply try to escape the darkness coming in from the left. In total the game has many hours of gameplay, and lots to give. 7.6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197975373553', 'num_games_owned': 1873, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 1084, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1084, 'last_played': 1457452079}
review: I found this game to be polished and nice looking, but the gameplay is lackluster and mind-numbingly repetetive. The same bullet dodging goes on for 8+ hours and upgrades and units make very little difference, Maybe it would play better on a tablet? As a pc-gamer I expect more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022266051', 'num_games_owned': 3249, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 647, 'last_played': 1457199537}
review:
[h1]A decent "tower defense" game where you play, get gold, die, buy upgrades, and repeat until you're finally able to fend off all the advancing hordes.[/h1]

So in that sense...it's pretty repetitive, especially the beginning levels since you have to play them so much to level up your favorite companions to then make it further in the game.  Your companions are the only way to attack enemies for you are the bard player, their leader, and they trail behind you or just in front of you whever you go.  For companions, you do get a wide variety that unlock as you progress in the game, from short range heavy damage, to long range low damage, healers, and other abilities, etc.  I found if I just picked a couple to focus on and upgrade those, I found I could go farther.

For what it is, the game is pretty well done and I had a pretty good time, but the game could definitely use more music -- that just added to the repetitive feeling of the game.

[h1]The Good:[/h1]
[b]+ Nice graphics.[/b]  I like the style and the theme of the game.
[b]+ Nice style of gameplay.[/b]  Leading the companions to do the attacking for you.
[b]+ Entertaining.[/b]  I not only finished the campaign but continued on to complete some additional Steam Achievements.
[b]+ Nice upgrade options.[/b]  You can upgrade yourself (health, speed, number of followers, etc), your companions (health, damage), and your town (pet, health/gold bonuses while playing, strength, defenses).
[b]+ Couple other game modes.[/b]  [u]Survival Mode[/u] where you just run around (not in town) and see how long you can survive where you are given a few periodic random drops like bacon (for health) and followers.  And [u]Distance[/u], where without any followers you see how far you can run without taking a single hit.  They're both fun for a few attempts, but I like that they were included.

[h1]The OK:[/h1]
[b]~ Every level the same.[/b]  It's always your town.  The monsters change.  Nothing else.  Not even the lighting despite the levels being grouped into different times of the day.  (Morning, Noon, Evening, Night).

[h1]The Bad:[/h1]
[b]~ Too repetitive.[/b]  Felt too much like grinding the same levels over and over to get gold to level up your guys to survive longer.

[h1]Overall:  This is a fun Tower Defense game with a 5.7hr campaign (for me), suffering only from being too repetitive early on.  7.5 out of 10.[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197994240027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1453708257}
review:
Suffers from the same problem as all tower defense games, but even worse.

The game is clever enough but destroys itself with constant, required grinding. The gameplay is unique overall, but you plain cannot fight through a level without passing a stat check you will not reach through normal play. Your damage will simply be too low to kill the hordes fast enough.

What seemed like a fun game has turned to trash because a terrible upgrade/exp system built only to waste your time rather than to give choice and meaningful growth.

review: Grindy and not terribly engaging. It looks and feels like something you'd play briefly on Kongregate or Newgrounds. Plays a bit like Snake crossed with a bullet hell shooter, only your satellites have HP and do the brunt of the damage, and you're constantly grinding gold for ~upgrades~.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010739000', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1583007675}
review:
I didn't really know what to expect out of this game. Thankfully, it's not so hard to pick up. It throws you right into the game without any notable intro/knowledge but don't worry, figuring everything out is a matter of few minutes. It doesn't take long and you will be addicted to [i]Bardbarian[/i].

[b][h1]======OVERVIEW======[/h1][/b]

[i]Bardbarian[/i] takes the Tower Defense genre to a whole new level, where you can actually influence the outcome of a battle, whether you just move differently or have other units spawned. Every level usually somehow differs each time you play it. However, if you play a certain level few times, you can actually remember when and where a specific enemy spawns. That being said, it is not a big deal since you'd have to spend too many hours in this game to actually remember the pattern of spawning. Besides the regular adventure/story mode, there are two more game modes: survival and escape. Both of them bring a fresh air if you're just burnt out of the main mode and I must say that surprisingly enough, I've enjoyed these. Plus you can unlock some of otherwise not approachable units and you can come up with some other interesting strategies. So far I'm using ordinary units more but might give those specials try if I ever struggle with some specific level. And yeah, you'll find yourself struggling with a level more often than you're willing to admit but don't worry, it gets better with almost every upgrade. Far better when you find yourself some comfortable unit combinations. One more noticable thing: sound. The way this game works with soundtrack and sound effects is just beautiful.

[b][h1]PROS[/h1]
- visual side
- controls/gameplay
- trading cards
- sound effects and soundtrack
- grinding
- replay value
- achievements + trading cards
- crossover features with other indie games

[h1]CONS[/h1]
- lacks events/seasons updates [i](last update was on Halloween, still in the game to this game which kinda doesn't make sense)[/i][/b]

[b][h1]======RATING======[/h1][/b]
I love this game. It sets the standard for Tower Defense games too high and it'll honestly be a hard quest for other games to overcome the great experience I've had playing Bardbarian. I'd highly recommend it to every casual gamer out there, heck, even to those hardcore gamers, you can spend some quality time playing this game as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055232329', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1455519314}
review:
Bardbarian is called a tower defense, but it plays like a shoot em up. You control a bard who doesn't attack, but leads around some helper minions who automatically shoot at any enemies they see. After every death you can upgrade your hero, helper units, or town bonuses.

The game is not very long, but there is enough content, and the music is great. Dying isn't so bad because you can just upgrade something and return more powerful next time to progress further.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963485875', 'num_games_owned': 1683, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1705703594}
review:
Bardbarian is a nice tower style RPG action defense type of game (if that is even a thing?!)

[b]Gameplay[/b]

In Bardbarian you play as Brad who set's out to defend the precious towns Crystal (and protecting all the residents of the town) calling upon the help of various useful warriors, ninja's, medics etc that are all available for you to choose your own army.
The core mechanic of the game is basically a scrolling from left to right action fest where anything that moves or comes your way from the right you must use your own chosen small army to ensure they are taken out before they come anywhere near the town's crystal and inflict damage.
Bardbarian is a large game that has tonnes of replayability and XP grinding (that doesn't seem much of chore). It has a nice mechanic that keeps the game flowing along nicely allowing you to upgrade your arsenal of chosen Warriors after each fight is over!

[b]Graphics/Music[/b]

Being an Indie game it is sometimes hit and miss with what graphics can be on offer but I personally found the overall 'sheen' and 'quality' to be of a very high standard. 
The music seems to suit the game well, I liked the touch of the little guitar 'licks' each time you engaged Brad to summon a warrior or power. I accidently left the title screen music playing for about 30 mins on once occasion and it didn't grate on me either which is definitely not a bad thing.

[b]Pros/Cons[/b]

Pros 
+ Pleasing high-quality graphics and production.
+ A Casual game but still has that 'one more game before I turn it off.. appeal!'.
+ Wide arrays of characters for your arsenal of good guys.
+ Extra game modes to play alongside the main campaign.

Cons 
- Took a long time to figure out the correct (and best) upgrade paths for your team.
- Can have a frustrating one hit death to your main character Brad at the most inconvenient times.

[b]Final/Personal Thoughts[/b]

Bardbarian is a high-quality Indie title that I personally enjoyed playing through, yes it can be frustrating at times but as soon as you have put some time and effort into the game it will reward you with revisiting the same levels but the game being a lot easier to conquer (having a team with fully upgraded warriors!).
Recommended purchase if on sale or part of a bundle!

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://twitter.com/osgamegeek - Check out my Twitter Feed

author: {'steamid': '76561198043898178', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1422747893}
review: Finished the campaign and tried the side games. Worst game I've played this year so far, I'm mostly baffled by how they completely missed the point of a tower defense game: it's the first game I can remember where you're supposed to lose countless times before winning, you literally can't win the game on your first try. That's a pretty big design fail in my opinion: one of the most important mechanics in a tower defense is being able to buy and upgrade units on the go, in order to adjust to what the waves of enemies contain; here you can't, you just choose three type of units at the beginning and that's it, you can't even upgrade on the field, you have to lose to do it (but you have to grind the money playing and dying soo thereafter), of course the units are severely underpowered at first so the whole system falls on itself and crumbles. Disappointing in almost every way.

Bardbarian √© um jogo sandbox em que voc√™ assume o papel de um b√°rbaro somado com um bardo "BardBarian" (para quem n√£o sabe um bardo √© aqueles m√∫sicos das idades antigas)

Seu objetivo √© proteger um pequeno reino que esta sobre constante ataque de v√°√°√°rias e v√°√°√°rias ondas de inimigos, a cada onda vai ficando mais complicado e vai aparecendo inimigos com diferentes habilidades.
Para proteger este reino, voc√™ usa sua guitarra para tocar diferentes sons, com essas musicas que voc√™ toca, voc√™ invoca/chama novos refor√ßos e pode ativar buffs e melhorias para voc√™, suas unidades e o Reino.

J√° ouvi pessoas comparando este jogo com um tower defence... mas sei l√°... n√£o vejo muito TD nesse jogo.
Voc√™ na verdade apenas contrata tropas que ficam seguindo seu personagem, essas tropas atacam as unidades inimigas pr√≥ximas, seu bardbarian ganha XP conforme avan√ßa nas ondas e mata inimigos, e com esse XP upa suas tropas e compra novas habilidades e melhorias...
Ent√£o basicamente seu √∫nico objetivo √© andar pelo mapa tentando desviar dos ataques inimigos e fazendo suas tropas atacarem automaticamente as unidades pr√≥ximas...
Ao meu falar o jogo pode parecer mon√≥tono n√£o √©? Mas √© ai que voc√™ se engana...
Ele √© muito divertido e viciante, voc√™ sempre tem vontade de passar mais uma onda e conseguir mais dinheiro e XP.
Recomendo-o com toda certeza :D

O jogo conta com uns outros modos de jogo, como sobreviv√™ncia e uma esp√©cie de corrida em que seu personagem segue uma linha reta com v√°rios obst√°culos...
Alem do modo Hardcore que √© 10x mais dif√≠cil que o modo normal de jogo.

O jogo conta com algumas referencias a outras jogos indies que achei interessantes :P

As gr√°ficas do jogo s√£o 2D cartunizados, √© um estilo que achei muito simp√°tico.

review:

Das Spieldesign habe ich so auch noch nicht gesehen hat etwas von einem RPG und auch ein paar MOBA Elemente.

Fazit: wem gerade langweilig ist und wer nichts zu tun hat holt sich einfach Bardbarian (aber f√ºr das Handy, macht meiner Meinung nach viel mehr Sinn als f√ºr PC) und spielt ein paar Runden :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198069794444', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2304, 'last_played': 1452882472}
review:
*Trying to get the last achievement for the past 6.000 hours*

- Finally gets to wave 41,
- Last 2 bosses shoot at me, 
- I dodge, 
- the shot goes through the whole map and hits my castle
- Dead.

*add + 2.000 hours* 

- Finally gets to wave 41 again,
- Only 2 bosses left again,
- I'm super confident 'cause my castle has full health,
- I dont see a fireball coming from the sky,
- Dead.

*sells own soul to satan and infuriates myself with every last bit of rage, which is the only thing that still keeps me going*
- Gets to wave 48 ->  and also get the 48¬∫ place in steam official rank -> YEAH MOTHER******, 
- you beautiful, beautiful achievement, come to daddy
*achievement still not showing*
- hum, that's strange,
- goes looking for the achievement descripiton
- been playing in normal mode till now, achievement is in insane mode.

I hate this game 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198076826804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1097, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1097, 'last_played': 1417336392}
review:
I found this an interesting twist on Tower Defense games. Instead of having the enemies on a set path, they just all come in where ever, and you have to drag the 'towers' behind you. Also, there's a bit of a bonus for fans of a few other games in there, in the form of special heroes/towers you can unlock in the various modes.

Music's a bit repetitive, though.

review:
Well, that was highly entertaining. Music gets a bit repetitive. Gameplay is smooth (with a controller at least), and the different allied units allow for some customization of your play style. Worth paying full price for though. I regret nothing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044395534', 'num_games_owned': 269, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 711, 'last_played': 1450538913}
review:
Cosa fa un Barbaro quando √® stanco di grindare mostri per drop e XP? Smette di combattere e diventa un Bardbaro! 

Devo ammettere che ero scettico rispetto a questo gioco. Il trailer √® semplice ma invitante, e sebbene ami questo tipo di gioco demenziale (e il metal) pensavo mi avrebbe deluso. E invece no. √à semplice, √® divertente, e a un certo punto diventa molto difficile e costringe a pensare a strategie particolari per superare i livelli.

Fondamentalmente, questo gioco √® una parodia del classico D&D: il Bardo, incapace di fare null'altro, suona e buffa gli alleati. In questo caso, la musica serve sia a buffare il party che a costruirlo, evocando delle unit√† da scegliere da un pool di una ventina di personaggi (inizialmente, sono solo due o tre, poi si sbloccano tutti). I buff e le invocazioni vengono da assoli che Brad (il protagonista) fa con la sua arma/chitarra. 

Devo ammettere che mi ha sorpreso, e divertito per il suo costo (pagato 99 centesimi durante i saldi). Se siete interessati, provate la versione mobile che √® gratuita!

ROCK ON!

author: {'steamid': '76561198043051654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1449583579}
review:
very fun! 

you are Brad, a barbarian in charge of defending the town, who got bored of midless brawling and decided to become a bard. so you into this arena and have to defend the town against waves of monsters. the goal is prevent them to destroy a big diamond (kinda like the emperium in WoE, if you've played ragnarok online). to do that, you summon some fighters by playing solos with your axe-like-guitar. you can also play solos to buff yourparty, one for attack, one for defence and one for speed. there is also a stun solo, which you can use after playing a few songs (5 in a row if i'm not mistaken); this stun solo does literally what it says, leaves all foes inside a certain radius paralyzed. to perform your songs you spend musical notes, which generate with time (faster when you stand still) or when it drops. monsters also drop gold, which you can use to buy upgrades (buffing summons, buffing songs, increasing your life and many others). 

there are also two other game modes: survival and i forgot the name of the other one. but i haven't played them yet.

 in my oponion, only two problems: 

1) every 30 minutes there is a bug that doesn't allow me to play the solos anymore. i have to restart the game so it starts working again. the first two times, you think that's ok, but it gets very annoying when it keeps happening.

2) the soundtrack is cool, but mind-numbing repetitive. even the solos and the summoning songs are cool at first, but get boring once you've heard them for the 100th time.

other than these two issues (which are frustrating) i think this is a very cool game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198021965602', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1448381255}

author: {'steamid': '76561198000113517', 'num_games_owned': 316, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1449378610}
review:
I'm personally a big fan of tower defense style games, my absolute favorite beig Orcs Must Die! 2. Bardbarian, however, is a very close second.

With Bardbarian, you don't actually do any attack yourself, or set up towers that attack lanes of enemies. Instead, you move freely about the battlefield, commanding your troops who you bring in with "Sick Lute Licks," which in turn attack the enemies who come in from the right side of the screen. With a variety of attackers (Some long range, some short), a variety of enemy types, and a slew of upgrades to make your life easier, it's a fun game to play...if only for a few hours.

The main issue I personally have with the game is that there is litle longevity to it. Once you learn the enemy types and ugrade everythin to max, you could probably beat the game within 6-8 hours, even less if your quick about upgrading your stuff. Even the addition of an insane mde, which barely amps up the difficulty itself, isn't enough to satisfy me for very long. The game does however, have three main games modes.

The campaign is split up in to four sections with five levels each. At the end of each level is a boss. Beat the waves, beat the boss, move on. Simple enough. The other two modes aren't so standard. Survival has you in an enclosed area with enemies coming from all angles. Instead of summoning your troops like you do in hte campaign, you find them on the field. This is nice because the notes you generate to normally summon units can be diverted solely on powerups for them. It stinks because they don't spawn into the gamtoo quickly, and you are often times left defenseless, seeing as you are unable to attack on your own. The final mode is Escape, and its basically a run right as long as you can while a wall of death follows you. You collect gold along the way and avoid enemies, making it a good mode to make some quick gold if you need to.

All in all, the first few hours of the game were just plain fun for me. Unlocking new allies was always nice, and upgrading them, the town and myself added that extra touch. The other games modes were a lot of fun too. But as I stated befor,e once you get into the 6 hour mark, and have upgraded almost everything...it get sold fast. If the game has any future updates, I'm unaware, so as of right now, it's a good experience, but for a limited time.

If you want a game to kill a few hours with, I highly recommend it. If you want something that will keep you entertained for a long time...this will help ease the pain of waiting for Fallout 4 to download...

If you thought this review was helpful, let me know! I like doing these, and plan on doing more for the other 190 games I own, so please let me know if this helped! Also, check out some of the other reviews I've done, and have fun playing!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011275042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1447104099}
review:
A game with a lot of unexplored potential. Feels like a flash game you could be playing for free on kongregate. The units are pretty creative and varied, but the rest of the game is the same old thing time and again. No matter how many stages you beat you'll never leave the same area and for a game about a 'bard' it sure has a POOR variety in music...

You can do almost nothing besides summoning units and roaming around with them dodging projectiles while they do all of the job, leaving you to activate powers every now and then and that's about it. This game grows boring early. I bought it dirty cheap during a sale so no regrets here but I don't think I'd ever reccomend this to anyone.

I find it funny that the character in the main screen follows your mouse with the eyes and his expression changes depending on where you hover over the screen... And he smiled when I hovered through the "Quit to desktop" button. Even the main character agrees that you're supposed to quit this game. Clearly the devs could have done a lot better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011596215', 'num_games_owned': 1637, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1446680125}
review:
TLDR: Wer Gefallen an Tower/Base-Defense findet und Spiele mag, bei denen der eigene Skill einen gut voran bringen kann, dem wird dieses Spiel wohl gefallen!

-------------------------

Dieses Spiel hat mir sehr viel Spa√ü gemacht! Ich habe es mir relativ "zuf√§llig" heruntergeladen, gestartet und dann hat es mich direkt "gepackt".

Im Spiel steuert man den Charakter "Brad" dem eine Armee folgt, die man sich selbst zusammen stellen kann (beispielsweise: Bogensch√ºtzen, Magier oder Octodad). Die Einheitengr√∂√üe der eigenen Armee h√§ngt von Upgrades ab, die sich im Verlauf des Spiels freischalten lassen. Allgemein l√§sst sich so ziemlich alles im Spiel upgraden - f√ºr mich ein Pluspunkt!

Mit seiner Armee soll Brad den Base-Kristall (ganz links auf der Map) vor den Gegnern besch√ºtzen, die von der rechten Seite der Map kommen. Um die Base zu verteidigen muss sich Brad diesen Gegnern also stellen - und deren Angriffen im besten Fall ausweichen um nicht zu sterben! Brad selbst kann zwar nicht angreifen, aber er kann seine Armee mit verschiedenen Verst√§rkungen unterst√ºtzen (Mehr Schaden, mehr Lauftempo oder h√∂here Verteidigung). Doch diese Buffs sind - so wie seine Armee - nicht umsonst. Sie kosten Noten, welche Brad durch das Spielen auf seiner Laute oder im Verlauf einer Spielsitzung bekommt - ein sinnvoller Einsatz ist also gefragt!

Ebenfalls bietet das Spiel mehrere Modi:
‚Ä¢ Story mit 4 Bossen und mehr (lasst euch √ºberraschen)
‚Ä¢ Survival (√úberlebe so lange du kannst!)
‚Ä¢ Escape (Versuche so weit zu laufen wie m√∂glich)
sowie zwei Schwierigkeitsstufen (Normal und Insane)

Ebenfalls gef√§llt mir der Humor der Entwickler (Ein Beispiel daf√ºr ist die Achievement "360noscopeblazeit") und allgemein das Gesamtpaket.

Die gerade einmal 4 Bosse h√∂ren sich zwar wenig an, jedoch wird es - wahrscheinlich - ein wenig dauern, bis ihr dorthin gelangt. Entweder es scheitert an der Zusammensetzung eurer Armee oder an eurem Skill :P

Klingt gut? Ist es auch!

author: {'steamid': '76561198091074270', 'num_games_owned': 954, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1486243896}
review:
Stavo sfogliando le pagine del negozio di Steam quando ho notato questo gioco. Apro la pagina e due secondi dopo dico: "DEVO COMPRARLO!". Cos√¨ l'ho comprato (dato che era pure in sconto) e ho iniziato subito a giocarci.

Premetto che non ho ancora finito la modalit√† storia (ho appena sconfitto il boss del mezzogiorno) e che qundi una volta finito modificher√≤ (se necessario) questa recensione.

Il gameplay √® simile a quello di un comune tower defense, ma  in questo caso l'eroe (Brad) non fa danno direttamente, bens√¨ aiuta le sue "truppe" con gli assoli della sua ""chitarra"" (non √® una chitarra, ma non saprei come descriverlo). Non √® facile, sopratutto all'inizio ma una volta capito il meccanismo si riesce ad andare avanti pi√π facilmente. I boss e alcune truppe speciali sono pi√π difficili da sconfiggere. Mi piacerebbe avere pi√π di 3 personaggi in quanto come detto precedentemente il gioco diventa sempre pi√π difficile.
Mi piace molto la variet√† dei personaggi e anche che alcuni di essi appartengano ad altri titoli (octodad, il personaggio di super meat boy, etc).
La grafica √® ben fatta.

Adesso veniamo a un punto MOLTO importante per questo gioco: la soundtrack.
Una parola: FANTASTICA! 
La musica rock si adatta alla perfezione in questo videogioco, rendendo il gameplay meno noioso.

Che dire, ve lo consiglio!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011533232', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1446219097}
review:
This is a flash game, and not a very good one, AND you have to pay for it. It's not worth to pick it up even if it's on sale. Just go on Kongregate and play games that are much better AND FREE. 

Why is it bad?

1. The pacing. It's pretty tough untill you get Wizards, a cakewalk afterwards. You don't need to use other units.
2. The GRI-I-I-IND. There's a ton of grind in this game, and it's not even satisfying. You grind for gold, you spend it on upgrades. And there's no visual difference between a maxed out unit and a lvl 1 unit.
3. Isn't that enough?

DON'T. BUY. IT. It's a shitty timewaster, there are better ones.

review:
I originally loved Bardbarian for its humor and deep skill tree, but it ended up being too simplistic in a lot of ways.  Graphics, music, and sound are all subpar, and gameplay involves trying to avoid projectiles with a swathe of party members you can't really control.  The formula also involves a grind to become powerful enough to get further.

Overall, this wasn't enjoyable for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004581037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 821, 'last_played': 1433698666}
review:
A fun little game where your offense lies in your allies rather then yourself. 

   I got to say, I love the premise of this game. Being D&D player for many years, I've always seen Bards get the short end of the stick. This one puts the bard center stage at the heart of the party in a funny action-packed way. Lots of dodging, explosions, death, and all in a nice little pg-13 package. 
   Gameplay is good, though I've only played Bardbarian on PC. The wealth of party members make for some interesting combinations, giving you a lot of leeway on play style. It's a simple, straight forward game that can give you hours of entertainment.

   Not real complaints on this one oddly enough. Thoughrolly enjoyed this one from start to end. Even managed to clear all the achievements, which almost never happens with me.

   Bardbarian is definetely one to add to the library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031582331', 'num_games_owned': 6781, 'num_reviews': 768, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1561626020}
review:
7min of gameplay
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6H54Tuvvcpo

5/10 tis cute

This game is like a action rts.
Your main character does not attack but can summon or rally his troops.
He has a little racoon pet that can be upgraded to fetch things like gold or items from the town folk.
You pick 3 out of up to 15 classes to take into battle to summon them and help you fight.
Bard will slowly gain notes over time or they can be dropped from enemies.
These are used to call in a unit or to use 1 of the 3 buff that will increase your party's attack, defense, or speed.
The villagers and fort can also be upgraded so they give you items and add defenders to your fort.
In the main story you play through 4 sets of 5 levels with the 5th always being a boss (there is also a days 2).
In Survival enemies and friendly units will randomly spawn on the board and you try to see how long you can stay alive without any bard powers.
In escape mode you have no bard powers and try to see how far you can get wile avoiding poison pools, enemies, & there shots.

Overall its not a bad take on rts games and the units do vary and will change your play style depending on who you bring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106810138', 'num_games_owned': 2232, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1425138611}
review:
You are a barbarian that is tired of pillaging and wants to be a bard instead.
So, Bardbarian. The entire backstory is there in the title.

Unfortunately this new devotion to music and abhorrence of inflicting violence could not be timed worse, since an invasion force of monsters is approaching the quiet town you live in.
Why? Nobody knows. There is no plot beyond the setting.

This leaves the town in a pickle though, without the barbarian they will need another way to protect their town.
Despite no longer fighting directly the Bardbarian has decided to help. The local adventurers' guild has plenty of warriors around and all they need to join the defence is some encouragement. Musical encouragement.

So the Bardbarian runs around the battlefield, playing (monotonous but fun) music to gather a resource called Notes. These notes can be spent to recruit warriors from the adventurers' guild who will start following you around the battlefield, attacking any enemies that come close.

This turns the game into a defence game, you navigate your group of adventurers around the battlefield to keep the monsters away from the town square where a magical crystal does... something important, apparently. Wave after wave, until you get a boss fight and move on to the next segment of the game and do it all over again.

After your almost inevitable failure you spend the gold you earned from the enemies the adventurers have vanquished to upgrade... quite a lot of different things. Upgrade your units, unlock new units, upgrade your own stats, research spells and facilities around the village that make your time just a bit easier.
A weird item that you can buy is the Golden Guitar, which doubles all future Gold income. It's a relic of the time where the game had a cash shop on mobile, but fortunately it can be bought with regular currency in this Steam version. You should do that as soon as possible.

All in all the game gets a bit repetitive as it goes on, and some of the later units are so much stronger than the other ones that you don't really feel like you're customizing so much as levelling that one unit until you get past the level you're stuck on.
However, it's a pretty game with a lot of content and a solid soundtrack.
Recommended if you're looking for a fun defence game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998177676', 'num_games_owned': 4911, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1438390078}
review:
A bit hard to classify this game closest would probably be bullet-hell, except without you firing back as your hired NPC henchmen do that for you, with a touch of RPG and Rogue to finish it off. The cocktail is surprisingly good.

You can get notes (resource) by killing some foes, a certain unlockable structure and by standing still (generally ill-advised). With this you can then hire your henchmen, stronger ones unlocked as you proceed through the day (read: levels) and of course the more powerful the more costly. Upon dying you can use the second resource (gold) to permanently upgrade yourself or your henchmen.

It also comes with 2 minigames (to help gather some gold, both also unlock a henchman), one a running (just prevent getting hit) which is the least fun one IMO and a 'survival' mode where you randomly get henchmen to you with increasingly difficult enemies, which is a little more fun. But the best fun is of course gotten from the main game.
