author: {'steamid': '76561198124275446', 'num_games_owned': 1852, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1413856695}
review:
Bardbarian is a casual action game with hints of tower defense. I wasn't a huge fan of the game's cartoonish look, but tower defense is my favorite casual genre of game, and I go out of my way to try any game of the genre, whether it claims to add something new or not.

Bardbarian is fun in doses, but it quickly wears out its welcome. It adds something new to the tower defense genre, which is the fact that your "towers" are various characters that you can upgrade and you can influence their actions using music. You also have no stationary units (other than a full upgrade later on in the game where you can have units defend from on top of two buildings), and you are in charge of moving to the enemies and killing them off before they get close to your town center. While this is a new take on the genre, I didn't find that it added much enjoyment gameplay-wise, and in many cases, it turned out to be frustrating. You essentially have three entrances where enemies spawn, and the screen isn't large enough to cover the entire "field", so it's easy to be focusing on defeating enemies on one side of the screen and completely miss enemies coming through on the other side, because they are not visible on screen but only on the mini-map.

One of my favorite things about the tower defense genre is conquering maps and moving onto new challenging maps, and figuring out the best strategies for handling the routes enemies would take. Unfortunately, Bardbarian has one map, and one map only. It's understandable, in a way, because your towers are not stationary, so therefore new maps wouldn't be necessary. However, the game quickly becomes dull and repetitive because your surroundings are never changing. To add insult to injury, this game is one of the biggest grindfests I've ever played. Reading other reviews that state it was developed for phones now that I've played the game makes total sense, because this game sure does play like a phone game. Expect to play the same levels and waves of enemies over and over and over and over in order to save enough gold to buy even some of the most basic upgrades. Also, there are 20 waves of enemies, total, in the game. 20 waves TOTAL, which is equal to about one or two maps in most other tower defense games. The game only saves your level progress at every five levels, so if you don't beat the boss at the ends of levels 5, 10, 15, and 20, don't expect to start back on the level you died on. You have to go all the way back to the beginning of that "section" to try again.

Another issue I find with the game is the fact that your units are so easily killed, even when fully upgraded. Playing through a grindfest of a game to save enough for certain upgrades can be somewhat justified if those upgrades make the player feel as if it was worth it, but upgrading anything--anything, from the Barbarian's own health to his units or the town itself--feels ultimately underwhelming. 

The game also sports a survival mode (with one map to choose from) and an escape mode (one map). Both are ways to post high scores, add small value to the game, and potentially make a little extra gold. Survival mode is fun for a few tries, but escape wasn't really my cup of tea.

In summary, I began this review with the intention on giving the game a "recommended, but only on sale for $2.00 or less," but the more I thought about the game to write this, the more I realized I couldn't justify recommending it. In the end, it's up to you to decide, but I implore those fellow tower defense fans out there to find a different game of the genre to try. Bardbarian removes more enjoyment from the genre than it adds, and to be completely honest, it's possible that tagging this game as tower defense does it an injustice, because I went into this game wanting something that I ultimately did not get. Bardbarian can be fun, but it plays like an action casual phone or online Flash game. If you are willing to pay to purchase it with that in mind, you probably won't be disappointed. Otherwise, I'm sorry, but I cannot recommend this.

Edit 4/29/2016: I've noticed that an abnormal percentage of people have marked this review as unhelpful. As I always try my best to cover all aspects of a game in a review to be helpful to potential consumers, I would appreciate any comments on my review letting me know the information I've left out, or any questions you have about the game which my review left unanswered. I will update the review as applicable. Thank you!

review: I took a chance on this game cuz it was on sale on Humble Bundle, I looked at it and fell in love with the art style, and then i Played it and liked it even more, i havent played a tower defense like this game, and im a fan of the genre, if you enjoy grinding for upgrades and those type of games this is a game for you, if youre a casual gamer its also a nice game, I reccommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024246936', 'num_games_owned': 5024, 'num_reviews': 194, 'playtime_forever': 797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 796, 'last_played': 1417729752}
review: Bardbarian is fun, but it's the sort of simple and short-lived fun that makes it difficult to forget that it's a smartphone game at heart. All of the indie game tie-in characters add a flash of whimsy to this casual hybrid of Real Time Strategy and Tower Defense, but it's hard to gloss over the fact that you'll have experienced much of what the game has to offer in about 30 seconds of play. To its credit, the game packs in a lot of things to do in the form of different modes, minigames, and achievements. Unfortunately, the strategy aspect of Bardbarian is very shallow, and you can steamroll through about 98% of this game just by leveling any three units enough. Still, the action is instantly gratifying and the prospect of leveling your abilities to get just that little bit further makes the game addictive for the limited amount of time you'll spend on it. While I'd hardly call this game essential to your library, at the end of the day, I had $5 worth of fun and a good time getting all of the achievements.

review:
Bardbarian √® un tower-defense rispettabile. Nonostante sia un porting da mobile, i controlli sono ottimizzati bene, sia tastiera che joypad. Competitivo, ma √® soprattutto arduo, sembrerebbe facile... ma non √® tutto oro quello che luccica. Infatti il gioco √® impegnativo al massimo, e molte volte ti costringer√† a rifare tutto dall'inizio, ma non temere: questo √® il modo migliore per ottenere pi√π soldi per potenziare tutto, TUTTO. La grafica "fumettosa" inoltre √® fighissima, e (giustamente) non richiede troppo, anzi... Paragonandola ad altri titoli del genere indie, potrei dire niente in fatto di risorse.

Lo consiglio si, ma fossi in voi aspetterei qualche offerta.

review: I'm not a big fan of original tower defense type of games, but this one was pretty fun. Campaing was pretty easy even in insane mode but after finishing that 2 day -mode (which I suppose goes for infinity) opened and it was more challenging and fun to play. In campaings you can just stack same units and crush your way through but doing the same in 2 day -mode didn't really carry that far. I tried this game with keyboard and gamepad but I found gamepad to be much more pleasant experience.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198001502177', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1414373451}
review:
After first playthrough (about 1.5hrs), I recommend this game at the $5 price level.  Creative take on the tower defense genre (you and your units are the towers).

Pros:
Funny
Smooth mechanics
Enjoyable graphics
Good, and varied, tech tree/upgardes to customize to your play style
Creative take on the tower defense genre (you and your units are the towers)
Super easy to pick up and play for 15min here or there

Cons:
Shorter/less game time than I expected
Early upgrades are really easy but most units remain locked until later game
Not a free world/sandbox game or mode (which I misinterpreted from the description and video)

review: I bought this game while it was on sale for little over a dollar. I don't regret the buy at all. It's a cute little game, fun and great to play if you're looking for a game to play whenever you're in that bleh kinda mood, bored with the usual games. It shares a familiar feel of flash games, but if you're like me, that's just a plus. It's fun, unique and I would recommend it to anyone who loves flash games. Maybe buy it on sale though. At the $5 price mark, it's a little much for it in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034469286', 'num_games_owned': 1671, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3307, 'last_played': 1446162020}
review:
This game is so much fun!  It's basically a roving tower defense game where you play as a Bard and you summon companions that follow you around to deal damage or heal the party. Everything Bard does uses music notes that slowly refresh or can be dropped by monsters. The companions, Bard and even the town itself can be upgraded with gold dropped from monsters. Great music, art, humor and gameplay right now you can snag it at 75% off, although I do feel it's totally worth the regular asking price.

:D

author: {'steamid': '76561197993230678', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1443090133}
review:
I'm sorry, I can't hear you over the sound of my Guitar-Axe!

This game is a nice change over the standard tower defense games and I'm actually looking forward to playing it more. Normally TD games bore me after 10-15mins but this one has held my attention.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005592808', 'num_games_owned': 664, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 760, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 760, 'last_played': 1412396495}
review:
Imagine Plants Vs. Zombies if the plants had legs and you'd get a fairly close representation of this game. 
Pros:
- Solid controls
- Nice art
- Fun gameplay
- You really feel a sense of progression as you replay the levels with stronger guys.
- Multiple difficulty levels and game modes.
- Lots of replayability (to a point)

Cons:
- It can feel really grindy. The best way to get money is to start from Wave 1, but by the time you're comfortably passing wave 6 or 7 the earlier levels just stop being interesting.
- The song is nice for the first 2 hours. Then you're over it.
- Using the controller, there will sometimes be a bug where you can't use any of your powerups (special songs). This is basically game-breaking on insane mode.
- The extra game modes (survival, distance) are a little lame. It's neat they're there, but they're not very interesting.
- A few weird art decisions/errors. Some of the boss animations bug out upon defeat, and there's a few characters with poor/weird art choices (the zombies are in the style of Paper Mario, for example).

It's awesome fun. Pick it up on sale and you won't be dissapointed.
12 hours to 100% completion. Probably around 3 to play through the inital game once.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129799374', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1412290371}
review:
"Bardbarian" is a kind-of tower defense game with the towers being minions that you can spawn around you.

The further you get in the game, especially on Insane mode, it becomes a bullet hell shmup with different strategy approaches using a combination of 3 out of 15 minions like archers, mages, healers etc. It's your choice if you want a tanky front of paladins, followed by a group of mages to bomb your enemies and healer to support you and your team, or an army of knife-throwing ninjas and a single necromancer behind you, giving you a zombie meat shield up front (I chose that for Insane mode) or something completely different.

In addition, you get an awesome catchy Metal theme, cute graphics, lots of upgrades to purchase and the additional game modes Endless and Escape. All in all an awesome deal of many fun hours for a cheap price (especially when reduced).

I highly recommend this game to anyone that isn't disgusted by tower defense games and (not too hard) bullet hell shmups.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036590208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1478930492}
review: Very fun tower defense game, got it on sale and was well worth the price. Story mode has many unlocks to upgade your character and companions. If you get bored of that there are 2 dirrent game modes survival and endurance, each a new fun way to play the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098579338', 'num_games_owned': 234, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1562086162}
review:
Tower Defense Game.

   Even if im more of like "modern gamer" I enjoy playing this game.
Theres trading cards , its cheap , controller support , what can be better ?
I really enjoy getting to next levels. Though its really hard to get alot of money and get
passed the levels and get acviements. But well , I love this game. 
   Right now this is my FAVOURITE tower defense game. 
I think they should add multiplayer or co-op in the game though. That would be awesome.
If you could play in co-op with 2 controllers or 1 keyboard and controller and in multiplayer mode with
your friends , online ! That would be epic ! 
   The cartoon style in this game brings that enjoyment. Its really nice looking and totaly worth your money and time.
I recommend this game to everyone , every gamer. Modern or old style.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110070777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 722, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1653778056}
review: This game is very fun.  It is easy to pick up and play, and it does not punish you for not being great at first.  It is a tower defense game, but your character moves and does not attack.  Instead you enlist followers (like the defenses in a tower defense) and run around attacking goblins who are trying to get your town crystal.  I wouldn't buy this game for anything more than $5 (this is steam, there are hundreds of incredble games with hours of game play for under $5), but it is definitely worth a few bucks and 10 or so hours of your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970376854', 'num_games_owned': 1289, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1412215000}
review:
I didn't make the connection while playing, but I can now easily see where someone would classify Bardbarian as a 'tower defense' game where you move the towers around a big map.  

Though, by that same definition, Robotron and Smash TV might also be called 'tower defense'.  **mind blown**

Fun, quick and humorous. I've enjoyed this delightful little overhead shooter for a while on Android, but was frustrated by having my finger in the way of the action -- plays much better with a gamepad or mouse/keyboard.  Glad to see the developer brought it to the desktop.

On the down side, it's not particularly deep, and it's eventually as repetitive as one might expect. But hey: video games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070331779', 'num_games_owned': 659, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 465, 'last_played': 1609633988}
review: Ranging from its multiple character classes to its gala of easter eggs, this game screams fun. Creating different parties adds a tactical element to the game, allowing for many play-throughs. The upgrades provide a sense of accomplishment and the survival and escape modes offer more for one who completes the main game. Overall, while it can be classified as a standard iOS port, this defense game breathes a sense of enjoyment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012884331', 'num_games_owned': 586, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1413010605}
review:
I thought I'd hate this game.

If you're like me, you've been burned by plenty of bad indi-games in the past.

But I'll be damned if this isn't a great spin on the tower defense genre. 

I bought it for $1.25. I would easily pay full price for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048103773', 'num_games_owned': 713, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 828, 'last_played': 1407529815}
review:
Bardbiarian is a baby MOBA. No kidding! Its a single player MOBA on 1/2 a MOBA stage. You've got the 3 lanes spawning creeps and the goal is to defend the MOBA doohickey that will make you lose if destroyed. Its not difficult or complex.

On normal difficulty, this game stinks. Its insultingly easy. Bad enough I was going to give a negative review.

Hard difficulty... Well, that's where the game actually gets fun.

Bardbarian has a distinct newgroundsy free flash game feel to it. It also has annoying bugs that should be fixed but haven't. Also they didn't try to make the music loop properly which is way more annoying than you'd think. 

Anyway, I found myself enjoying the game. $5 is a bit much for the state the game is in. If its on sale and you've got pocket change burning a hole in your pocket, you can't go too wrong. Just wish they'd f-ing fix the obvious very common bugs though. If they did, I'd say, "yes absolutely. This game is worth throwing $5 at."

author: {'steamid': '76561197961397228', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1412249874}
review:
It's a pretty good little game, with lots of progressive features and game modes to keep it fresh. It can feel like a bit of a grind at times, but not too much. 

One thing holding me back from playing it too much is the random lagg occuring every now and then, sometimes making it unplayable. At certain points in the game there's a lot going on at the screen, and the last thing you need is the game lagging up like that. I've no idea why this happens, as I've got quite a powerful rig setup. And the game is pretty damn basic and doesn't demand a whole lot of resources, compared to other really heavy games which don't lagg my system at all.. 

But overall, it's pretty good. At least for the small ammount of money it costs. 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198040884867', 'num_games_owned': 2433, 'num_reviews': 901, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1497484413}
review:
This is an excellent game that is worth more than the small asking price. Also, the developers are great - root around the forum for many examples of this.

This game works great with keyboard and mouse or a controller (my personal favorite). It has awesomeness very similar to Plants vs. Zombies. PvZ is better in my opinion, but this is certainly up there. Only slight drawback to this is that I get bored when playing for any kind of long time frame. It is best to play in short bursts.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987456322', 'num_games_owned': 528, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1412162287}

author: {'steamid': '76561198065942301', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1482291442}
review:
Couple of guys working in a basement brought about this lovechild of "A Bard's Tale" and "Plants vs. Zombies".

Simple theme:
A warrior who's tired of killing vows never to swing his axe again and makes a lute of out it.  A few seconds later goblins start attacking.  You build up notes (form of currency) over time, and use them to hire different troops and buy 10 second buffs.  The goblins are trying to run up your yard and destroy the Town Crystal (a building at the other end of the yard) but will attack you if you get close.  There are several different types of goblins and monsters and after about 5 rounds, a boss of some sort, then you move straight on to the next level.  

You can play a Day Campaign (the levels Morning, Noon, Evening and Night), start from a previously-reached level, Survival Mode or Escape Mode (dodging scroller variant w/ no fighting).

Killing enemies also generates gold which can be used to upgrade just about everything multiple times.
Epic music, simple controls, fast gratification, and easy on the harddrive makes this good for a gamer's quicky.

As they say,
Go play some notes and kick some scroats.

review:
Totally worth the 1+euro for this game.
Probably one of the easiest games to get all the achivements in, if you're in to that.
Wouldn't recommend the game at it's full price. 
It's one of those game that you play through, get the achivements and then probably never play again.

If you buy the game, play a new game once installed and then just exit to menu and start a new game again, so you pick insane mode right away. It's not really any harder than normal at all + you get loads of more cash.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089289691', 'num_games_owned': 2958, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 574, 'last_played': 1405820423}
review:
Bardbarian es un port de un juego de iOS y que, se trae consigo casi el mismo contenido pero con algunas mejoras graficas, cameos tontos (en el buen sentido) a otras franquicias de videojuegos y sobre todo unidades extras de la escena indie de PC.

B√°sicamente este es un juego tipo "defensa de torres" en el cual tendremos que invocar ciertas unidades (dependiendo del costo que ellos precisen) para eliminar hordas de enemigos aunque al contrario de la tipica mecanica del juego, podremos movernos libremente siendo una especie de "torreta movil" con la que nuestros compa√±eros se moveran al unisono.

Como el dise√±o de juego es pensado para los videojuegos para celulares, hay ciertas cosas que podrias ver familiar como por ejemplo la adiccion que produce ya que, dentro de todo, es disfrutable. Lo m√°s criticable al respecto es que el juego da un salto increible de dificultad en los primeros niveles (o mas concretamente luego del primer jefe) obligandonos a jugar otros modos de juego para recolectar dinero y asi mejorar y comprar nuevas unidades que iremos desbloqueando.

Podr√≠a haber mucho m√°s contenido para la vida media del mismo, pero cumple con lo prometido.

[b]7/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198012730543', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1450993352}
review:
Bardbarian is a delightfully charming tower defense game. As Brad, the guitar playing barbarian, you lead your merry gang of friends (towers) around with you, defending your towns crystal from exploding. There are a large assortment of upgrades (both to your friends, yourself and your city) and the simple yet challenging game play makes for quite a bit of variation in your individual defending style. 

It's like Caterpillar meets Br√ºtal Legends meets Dungeon Defenders. Solid 4/5.

review: Bardbarian is a td hybrid. Your characters are "towers" that can move around, while trying to avoid getting hit by enemy projectiles. Simple, easy to learn, fun gameplay that gets better as you unlock and upgrade using gold from killing enemies. Has a few game modes, different difficulties and boss battles. For the price its a must for td or twin stick fans. Has more depth to it than most tower defense games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012710873', 'num_games_owned': 478, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1411337518}
review:
First of all, I started off "recommending" the game but after I wrote the review, I think it would be better the other way.

I have mixed feelings about the game. Even though I liked the game and finished the "Normal" mode, I don't feel like playing the "Insane" mode because I got bored a bit because of the repetitive gameplay (and the "Insane" mode doesn't seem to be offering something other than stronger/faster enemies in the same levels).

[b]Gameplay[\b]: Gets repetitive easily like most of the tower defense games and after the first boss, that's pretty much what you're going to see the entire game. "Survival" and "Escape" modes are not very addictive to play.

[b]Graphics[\b]: Nice but not the best. Some of the boss animations could have been better.

[b]Music / SFX[\b]: Really weak. You have pretty few sound effects in the game and 2 different background music, that's all. I think the developer should add "More Music and Sound Effects" to the future wishlist.


I recommend this game if you are a tower defense genre addict. Other than that, I don't recommend the game.

review: Decently fun horde-based bard-oriented carnage. Don't go looking for ultra depth but it's good fun while it lasts and offers enough variety. Fairly good challenge but relatively easy to 100% so for those who lack time (like me) that's always a plus. Recommended if you don't have much to play (which won't happen, I know) or if you want to pass time at work or something. Oh, it has loads of cameos of other indie game characters!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004453394', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 513, 'last_played': 1410991148}
review:
At 8 hours in I finally beat the game on normal mode, and unlocked NG+ (I'm not great at these games so your mileage will definitely vary).  I have enjoyed every minute of it, and will likely keep playing to try and beat NG+, or Insane mode.

This is a game that I put off buying at full price purely because it isn't my usual kind of game.  I saw it on sale for 69 pence, so thought it was worth a look.  It is definitely worth full price at ¬£3.99.  If there is a sequel I'll definitely be adding it to my collection.  If you see it on sale it is an absolute steal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085946143', 'num_games_owned': 1074, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 386, 'last_played': 1409842748}
review:
Do I recommend this game? Yes. With all my heart.

A Cute little game, which has you running around as the Bardbarian, Yes, A Bard/Barbarian. A Kick-ass entertainer, who's job is to play music through his battleaxe shaped guitar, and summon different warriors with the notes collected. The nights start out easy, a small amount of weak enemies, but that changes fast. This game, for a small price tag, will bring more entertainment than some of the larger titles.  Make sure you invest in the raccoon!

review: Fun little game, interesting take on a tower  defence, lots of upgrades, fun bosses to kill every so oftens and a few different game modes. Going for 100% is grindy to get all the gold but by end game gold is easy to get. Music and sound effects were pleasing although hovering over buttons seemed to cause a quiet screech. Worth buying on sale or in a bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022336820', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 668, 'last_played': 1460378524}
review:
An addictive and simplistic action-tower defense. Something of a hybrid between Defender's Quest, Nimble Quest and some shmup. Isometrical, fun and challenging - endlessly playable and cheerful, yet feels a bit hardcore in that you'd die a lot to progress (somewhat similar in the feeling as Rogue legacy, yet much more inviting). The upgrade system has unlocks for the longest of time, yet farming for gold never feels as such - there's always somewhere to progress and challenge to cross whilst doing so. Follower-character types are varied and gameplay is solid.

Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990695056', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1408860798}
review:
Bardbarian is way, way cool.  It's a remarkably-good mashup of tower-defence, overhead-view arena shmup, and console-RPG, with a couple of extra modes that not only add to replay value, but help advance the main game, too.

There's a lot of tongue-in-cheek humor going on here.  The gameplay is really solid -- I've never felt that I've been defeated unfairly -- it always feels to me as though I've screwed up something simple to get myself given out.

This game has a whole lot of "just one more go" in it... and the nice bit is that almost every go, no matter how poor it turns out, will help advance Brad, his entourage, and the town, just a bit further towards surviving the onslaught of evil.

In short, you will get a helluva lot of fun for your $5 (or less, on sale).  The artwork oozes character and style, and so does the writing (which is mostly descriptions of units and items, but still.. the humor and thoughtfulness shine even there).  It's a totally charming game and a great bending of the tower-defence genre.   I love that it plays very much like a bullet-hell arena shooter, though maybe not quite as hellish as real BH shmups.

author: {'steamid': '76561198150498780', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1408335367}

author: {'steamid': '76561198030080447', 'num_games_owned': 1277, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1409250544}
review:
Bardbarian is one of these games I went into "just to try", and find myself returning to now quite regularly. It has quite an original concept, being a tower defense with more than a twist. There is a central point to defend, and there are enemies coming in to attack, ever more, ever more strong. So far, so good.
But. The towers to defend your stronghold are not static, but are attached as party-members to the Bard you can steer around the battlefield, destroying enemies "on the fly" as it were. You do not attack yourself, but one can enhance the attacks of your party-members by playing short guitar-riffs, played free by collecting notes. Extra attack, speed, defence and a short freeze of the enemies come in handy as the waves of enemies get stronger. As usual, units and your Bard himself can be upgraded, for this one needs the coins the enemies drop in abundance.
In order to succeed, fast reactions and speedy thinking are necesarry. I found it difficult at first to keep an overview of the battlefield, as several issues need attention: where are the enemies coming in at thier strongest, which buffs are needed, did any of my units die so I have to summon a new one, is my stronghold still going strong, .... But after a while I got used to it and enjoyed running all over the place, with my little but brave party. Playing it with an Xbox 360-controller certainly helps and feels most natural.

Enemies get quite strong before halfway in the game, and so sustaining the 20 waves is no easy task. Every 5 levels there is a boss, but for the most part enemies do not change that much during the game. Still, with an extra "free run" mode (try to get as far as you can dodging the enemies) and with a "survival mode", one can come back to this game again and again. As can be expected nowadays, there are Steam trading cards and some inviting achievements, which really help to appreciate the game to the full. No classic, but still very enjoyable. Don't hesitate to buy this, especially when it's on sale or in a bundle.

Gameplay: 20/30
Graphics: 12/20
Sound: 9/10 (the combination of the sound-track and the guitar riffs works admirably well)
Longelivety: 14/20 (thanks to the extra modes, and to an extra difficulty level)
Technical & stability: 9/10
Personal rating: 7/10

Overall: 71/100

author: {'steamid': '76561198054877337', 'num_games_owned': 403, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1605913802}
review:
Bardbarian, combina os estilos [/i]snake[/i] e [i]tower-defense[/i]. O jogador controla apenas o bardb√°rbaro que lidera os companheiros que o seguem na peugada. A sua fun√ß√£o n√£o √© apenas direccionar o grupo, para evitar proj√©cteis inimigos ou investir contra a horda, √© tamb√©m tocar m√∫sicas de guerra que ir√£o melhorar o desempenho da companhia em termos de poder de ataque, poder de defesa ou velocidade, [b]numa din√¢mica que me divertiu por muitos mais horas do que esperava inicialmente.[/b]

Feita a apresenta√ß√£o percebemos que Bardbarian cont√©m todos os ingredientes para ser um √≥ptimo jogo casual. Por√©m, a dificuldade √© elevad√≠ssima! O modo ‚Äúnormal‚Äù √© dif√≠cil, obrigando o jogador a repetir n√≠veis demasiadas vezes e o modo ‚Äúveterano‚Äù‚Ä¶ Bom‚Ä¶ o modo veterano √© uma tareia. Ora, facilmente percebemos que um jogo falha a sua proposta de casualidade quando o jogador √© incapaz de o jogar casualmente! A repeti√ß√£o dos n√≠veis acaba por ser bem recompensada, com ouro e novas unidades, mas nenhum jogador casual gosta de perder sucessivamente.

A jogabilidade √© consistente e f√°cil de interiorizar at√© ao momento em que os inimigos aumentam em n√∫mero e a movimenta√ß√£o do nosso grupo passa a requerer muito mais precis√£o. Nesse momento percebemos que a forma como os aliados nos seguem √© imprevis√≠vel ou, no m√≠nimo, mal pensada, dificultando ainda mais a tarefa do jogador. Apesar deste problema tudo o resto √© bem concebido: o sistema de melhoramento de personagens e arsenal √© efectivamente √∫til e permite-nos planear uma estrat√©gia, as guitarradas t√™m um impacto real no jogo e as possibilidades de abordagem ao desafio, n√£o tendo a profundidade de um jogo de xadrez, s√£o simultaneamente simples e interessantes.
A abordagem √†s criaturas e ao design dos n√≠veis √© algo simplista. Creio que podemos recordar Plants vs Zombies para fazer referir uma boa pr√°tica. Nesse magn√≠fico t√≠tulo, o cen√°rio n√£o precisa de mudar para que o jogador se veja obrigado a recorrer a mudan√ßas estrat√©gicas. Isto porque os inimigos t√™m comportamentos de tal forma distintos √† medida que avan√ßamos no jogo que √© obrigat√≥rio repensar a abordagem, dando √† experi√™ncia um dinamismo constante. Em Bardbarian o cen√°rio √© invari√°vel e os inimigos n√£o acrescentam variedade suficiente para surpreender. Na maior parte dos casos s√£o apenas maiores e mais resistentes.

O grafismo e o som/m√∫sica s√£o tamb√©m simplistas e pouco apelativos. Sobre o aspecto visual n√£o h√° muito a acrescentar, por√©m, sendo a personagem principal um bardo, √© lament√°vel que a m√∫sica tenha sido t√£o desvalorizada: para al√©m de gen√©rica √© entediante e repetitiva.

No fim, para quem, como eu, √© f√£ de tower-defense, Bardbarian acaba por ser uma experi√™ncia divertida e viciante, que refresca dois g√©neros (snake e tower-defense), mas que, pela falta de criatividade na idealiza√ß√£o dos inimigos fica um pouco aqu√©m do seu potencial.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975295227', 'num_games_owned': 1880, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1457055114}
review:
I saw this game on sale and read the reviews.  Many people talked about it like it was a tower defense style game.  I'm not real big on tower defense.  You play a couple you've pretty much played them all.  But being the sucker for a good deal that I am, I picked it up anyway.
  
  Buying this game was like expecting a heat lamp hot dog from 7/11 and getting a finely crafted gormet meal with many layers of flavors I've had before but never in this blend and the preperation makes me want more.

  Another review called it a mix of Binding of Isaac and tower defense.  I would like to refine that a bit.  It's like Binding of Isaac mixed with Plants vs. Zombies.  You have the action of Binding of Isaac with the right to left enemies like Plants vs. Zombies.  Toss in a dash of Dungeon Defenders with the defending a giant crystal and a heap of Brutal Legend with playing your guitar to summon help or buffs.  Not to mention the great metal music like Brutal Legend.  Add just a pinch of bullet hell, except instead of flying a ship between the projectiles, you're steering a group through the gaps, and you have Bardbarian.

  Most of this game has been seen before here and there but put together like it is, it's one of the best surprises I've had in some time.  Even at the full price of $5.00, this game is a bargain.  I would definitely recommend picking this one up.  My first sitting with the game lasted over 5 hours and I have a short attention span and switch games frequently so that should say something in itself.  

Controls (with a controller. I didn't try it with a keyboard)  10
Sound  10
Graphics  9
Replayability  8
Addictiveness  10
"fun" factor 10
Overall  9.5

author: {'steamid': '76561198066115682', 'num_games_owned': 504, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1452618797}
review:
General tower defence game with a unique twist, whether that twist adds to the gameplay or not is a whole other question. Before I begin this review let it be noted I am not a huge tower defence game fan and I got it on sale for ¬£1.59. Let me begin

Pro:
+Unique twist of an ex-adventurer who has had enough of xp grinds and fighting bosses so has settled down to become a bard, summoning others to help him defend his town
+Upgrades
+Different game modes
+Steam trading cards
+Crossover units (Octodad, Shellraizer, Meat Boy)

Cons:
-Generic and does not bring anything new despite the twist suggesting so
-Not very much replay value unless you want all the upgrades, characters and achievements on normal and Insane difficulty levels
-Very expensive for what it is and can be matched by free browser title's
-has to have indie game crossover characters for people to want to play
-No resolution options
-Mediocre rock guitarist doesn't give a satisfactory soundtrack

Final Verdict;
Although it seems to offer something new it is really same old for this overpopulated stale genre of games. This did not add anything of note new to it, it is overpriced and even trying to spend as long as possible you will be lucky to spend 5 hours of time on the game. Saying this, it is not the worst game in its genre but not the best by a long shot


4/10

Monety przydadzƒÖ siƒô do rozwijania postaci, ulepszania miasta  itp. Dlatego polecam tƒÖ grƒô ≈õwietnie siƒô przy niej bawiƒô i serdzecznie zachƒôcam do zakupienia jej w sklepie Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064112136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1485, 'last_played': 1480160071}
review: I higher recommend this game. I've played far longer than I expected (purchased in a bundle). The difficulty ramp was definitely challenging, and the upgrades you can make to your units were perfectly timed to keep me interested in progressing further. By the time I reached the end of the game, my choice of units enabled me to blaze through all "Day 1" chapters with ease. This is probably the only game where I've gone after all achievements. EDIT: played again and still couldn't pu it down.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995865992', 'num_games_owned': 1198, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1406774325}
review:
Don't bother. This game isn't awful but you can find better similar games for free on Kongregate.

Your a bardbarian and you summon different units to fight waves of enemy and protect the crystal. You can use powerups and a stun attack to affect the battle but most the time your dodging projectiles and trying to get within the proper range of an enemy. You can upgrade the main character, the units and the town.

There just isn't much to this game. The campaign is actually pretty short but it pads itself out by making you grind gold for upgrades, which could be fun but the gameplay gets stale pretty quick so it just becomes a chore. The unlockable units are frustrating because you're not going to want to replace one of the units you have already upgraded - so you probably wont be changing your roster until later levels.  You have to pick 3 units you can summon for each run through, so a lot of the others will fall by the wayside. Your minions will miss constantly, especially long range ones.  The units give you a pretty wide hit area with how they stand around you (without upgrading), so a lot of dodging will involve turning another direction so your units mash together to get to the other side of you. So everything is pretty inprecise and skill doesn't come into play much, it's just comes down to grinding for those upgrades. The controller support is flawed, often you wont be able to preform the stun move and you have to restart the game for it to work again (at least on 360 controllers). Also, the soundtrack and sound effects are annoying and repetitive. I could see how this would be a better IOS game if you just wanted to mindlessly kill a few minutes but I wouldn't suggest buying it on Steam.  On the plus side it does have nice art and the Steam exclusive characters are pretty cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993115150', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1407371419}
review:
8/10. The artwork, design, and the fact that it's a tower defense game all sum up to the game looking just plain fun. 4 hours in,  and it's so far solidly fun and entertaining with good progression design. 

As for negatives, I'd say the biggest reason why I had it in my library for a while and didn't play it was because of the fuzzy concept of a 'bardbarian'. Hard to picture what that means when you're browsing games to buy/play. Also playing as a bard seemed kind of lame. Probably would've been more compelling to just call it "Barbarian Defense" or "Monster Slayer Defense" :).

review:
Immensely fun, but buggy. Several tmes I've been stuck with an unending attack song, I managed to freeze the game by dying during a stun song, and just now I died because the conrols and camera are locked temporarily when a boss dies, but bullets and other enemies aren't. For a bullet hell game, this often means death. You'd think they'd know that.

Still, it's really fun.

I'll admit that this game does seems clearly made for tablets at first, but the controls aren't terrible and it's fun regardless. It feels like a relatively well fleshed out game and doesn't have any weird pay to progress features. I feel like I"m consistently making progress every time I play, even if I don't get particularly far. It's a game that I play ten minutes at a time, but it's something I can reliably come back to and have a good time with every time I play.

I completely recommend Bardbarian for a few bucks if it looks interesting to you. It's pretty well executed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965551808', 'num_games_owned': 883, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 945, 'last_played': 1407799111}
review:
So, played for twenty minutes. Here are my initial impressions:

Very high production value. Great art. Well made music. Concise introduction and tutorial to the game. The suggestion to play with a controller in the beginning was spot on. Very smooth controls. In fact, the game mechanics are tight and extremely enjoyable. This isn't a "tower defense" game. It's actually a very refreshing take on that dynamic that I would argue sets it apart from tower defense. You're constantly running around, avoiding projectiles, while navigating your units in positions that will inflict the most damage. Gold collecting to boost the cards you have, along with collecting more cards adds a lot of replay value to the game as well. I'm already interested in trying all the different game modes to see what cards I can find. Not mention, indie game references to boot (Meat Sack card? Yeah, I want that).

A+ Best $2 I spent on Steam this year.

UPDATE: I ended up 100% this game, buying it for iOS, 100%ing it on that, and buying three copies for friends. Yeah, I ended up loving this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055373634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1410213310}
review:
Nice casual campaign game, 
The story line, story/campaign mode, is fairly simple, you play as Bert the Bardbarian, a barbarian who's tired of fighting and who's taken up playing the lute and comanding a troop of minions. You protect the town from evil creatures which are trying to steal (or destroy) the town's decorative diamond, and throughout the day more and more powerful creatures come at you in 'waves' (levels).
If you've played Rouge Legacy, this game's shop functions similarly, minus Charon stealing all your money. New minions are unlockable through playing through the end of levels, with the exception of two characters which are unlocked by playing the non-campaign levels. And, if you've played Octodad, Super Meatboy, or The Binding of Isaac and are a fan of those games, rejoice, you can unlock them as your minions too. They should really sell these games in a pack sometime.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999836504', 'num_games_owned': 3961, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1412695700}

author: {'steamid': '76561198027327381', 'num_games_owned': 685, 'num_reviews': 245, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1528199579}
review:
A very nice spin on tower defence. 

You spend whole game dodging projectiles while spawning units and using special abilities.
Visual style is very nice and appealing. 

Definitely one of the better mobile ports on the market if you don't mind it's somewhat grindy nature.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129417648', 'num_games_owned': 1495, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1485195808}
review:
The game is nice for people who love music. In the game, you're a hero who fights against a monster with your unit. So of the unit, you unlocked by waves or taking other gameplays mod. There are no checkpoints between games. Checkpoints are only when you did of the area then you can start from there. When you come in wave 4 you will unlock mage. She can heal you but when she heals you she gonna lose her life and if you want to she heal you will need to stay. The first boss will be in stage 5 the last stage of the morning. Then is the second boss in wave 10 then in 15,20 and last boss in 25 waves. You can upgrade you're hero, unit and castle.
In the game, you have skills which take 10 notes attack, speed and defence. Notes are in battle money you need for using skills and buying units. You have a special skill which stuns the enemy for a few seconds it's useful.

My rating for this game is 10/10 I love it and I don't need checkpoints between waves

author: {'steamid': '76561197993918433', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1498434715}
review:
UPDATE: New version seems to have fixed the issue with left trigger. Changing my review to recommend even though there is a sound glitch where the music stops playing and you cannot do any buffs. Not being able to buff is not as bad as not being able to summon followers.

Fun game with serious control glitches. I wish I could give this a thumbs up, but the control glitches are very severe and require you to restart the application. I use a wired Xbox360 controller to play the game. The left stick is movement, which works all the time. The right stick allows you to rotate melee or defense followers to face the enemy. This sometimes glitches, but not game-breaking. The buttons lets you jam out buffs or summon new followers. You toggle between the 2 modes by using the left trigger. This part glitches CONSTANTLY. Every single time I've fired up Bardbarian, I have run into that glitch. Here are the types of glitches I've run into so far. 1) The stun skill cannot be cast at all. 2) I cannot summon followers or cast buffs. 3) I can only summon followers. 4) I can only jam out buffs but not summon followers. Most of these glitches are game-breaking. The only fix I know is to quit completely and restart. If the developers really fix this issue (they tried a fix, it didn't work), I would definitely recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991709039', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1406749771}
review:
Bardbarian ‚Äì Heavy Metal in the Battle!

Towerdefense mal anders. Nun man schl√ºpft in die Figur von Brad und verteidigt
sein Dorf sowie auch den darin befindlichen (√ºberdimensionierten) Edelstein.
Die Steuerung ist einfach gehalten und schnell zu verstehen und das rasante 
Gameplay mit dem fetten Metalsound fetzt richtig gut. Mit der Zeit wird der 
Adrenalinspiegel kr√§ftig nach oben getrieben, den Welle f√ºr Welle werden 
die Nerven aufgrund immer st√§rkerer Gegner strapaziert.

An der Seite von Brad stehen individuelle NPC-Charaktere zur Auswahl die im 
Kampf eigenst√§ndig agieren. Durch besondere Eigenschaften von Brad werden 
ihre F√§higkeiten kurzzeitig verst√§rkt. Jeder Charakter ist anders und hat spezielle 
Begabungen, mancher ist stark im Nahkampf, andere haben Distanzwaffen 
wie Pfeil und Bogen oder Zauberspr√ºche und auch K√§mpfer mit Heilkr√§ften 
schlie√üen sich mit an. Die Einheiten halten sich immer in unmittelbarer Umgebung 
von Brad auf, so dass man auch immer Mitten in der Schlacht ist.

Durch das im Spiel gesammelte Gold ist es m√∂glich sein Team sowie auch Brad 
und vieles andere ebenfalls zu verbessern bzw. aufzuleveln. Infolgedessen 
ist man in der Lage immer mehr Angriffswellen zu √ºberwinden bis schlussendlich 
das eine gro√üe Ziel Endboss erreicht ist.

Zusammengefasst kann ich sagen f√ºr ein doch sehr kosteng√ºnstiges Spiel bin 
ich sehr  erfreut was mir geboten wird und selbst f√ºr kurze Sessions, wenn 
man mal nicht so viel zeit hat, kann man immer ne kleine Runde einlegen um 
das Gold Pensum zu erh√∂hen um letztendlich alles was m√∂glich ist bis aufs 
h√∂hste Level zu bringen.

Und nun -Let's Rock-

author: {'steamid': '76561198050634486', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 37, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1405739132}
review: I really like the writing and art for this game however the actual gameplay is very dry and dull. There have been flash games that have done the same style gameplay in a much more exciting manner with a higher skill curve. If some things were changed in game, or maybe if more features worthy of a downloadable title were added, I'd be all over this. Additionally, the music gets repetative after the first 400 loops. I can't believe I spent money on this, but maybe the sequel will offer something worth actual money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009778432', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1419396758}
review:
This is my favorite game I picked up on this year's Summer Sale so far, though its worth full price.
Basically make a party that follows you around, and lead them to fight bad guys and dodge their attacks. You can also buff them in a couple different ways. There's a lot of characters to unlock and upgrades to earn. Really fun casual game that makes you want to play just one more round- and there's a lot of rounds to be had.
Some people have said its grindy, but I don't mind. I felt getting the golden axe as soon as possible dramatically helped. I also think you should concentrate on a few things at first, and don't spread your money around too much other than some of the cheaper upgrades. I found the pet to be well worth unlocking, and the town is helpful to keep you going.
Using a controller definitely makes gameplay better- as soon as I switched from keyboard to controller, I was doing noteably better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014440353', 'num_games_owned': 1088, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 721, 'last_played': 1405528275}
review:
Bardbarian is a action tower defense game where movement, upgrades, and abilities are key. Song notes represent the unit currency of the game that allows you to hire or buff your recruits.. Units are active, which makes movement important, staying still will result in them being hit, or worse you being killed. The focus relies on player movement rather than building towers to re-route enemies. 

Endless and Survival are two side mini-games which provides cash based on performance, that helps upgrade units for the main campaign. You can unlock characters by accomplishing certain feats on both modes. Endless mode is when you are running and trying to survive all the bullets on the screen, accumulating as many miles as possible which I found a welcome mix-up from the normal gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064649288', 'num_games_owned': 768, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1405630509}
review:
[b]Bardbarian ist eine Mischung aus Tower Defense und RPG und stammt aus dem Entwicklerstudio: TreeFortress Games.
Meiner Meinung nach ist "Bardbarian" eine Indie-Perle. Trotzdem gibt es einige Sachen die ich kritisieren muss.[/b]

Nachdem ich nun den Normalen Modus abgeschlossen habe und auch ein bisschen im Endless + Survival mode experimentiert habe, wird es nun auch Zeit ein Review zu diesem einzigartigen Spiel zu verfassen. Eigentlich ist das Spielprinzip sehr einfach und auch das Ziel ist schnell erkl√§rt: Bek√§mpfe alle Monster und besch√ºtze den Kristall. Typische Tower Defense Manier eben. Zudem kommt auch dass man selber gar nicht angreifen kann. Jedoch kann man auch keine T√ºrme oder √§hnliches bauen. Man kann daf√ºr aber Einheiten "beschw√∂ren" indem man einen Gitarrenriff spielt. Skurille Idee, die aber sehr stimmig und aussergew√∂hnlich r√ºberkommt. Diese Einheiten laufen dem Spieler hinterher und greifen auch selbstst√§ndig an. Als Spieler muss man versuchen die Einheiten m√∂glichst an die Gegner ranzubringen und feindlichen Geschossen auszuweichen oder man spielt mit der Gitarre Riffs damit die Einheit zum Beispiel f√ºr eine bestimmte Zeit mehr Schaden macht oder auch dass man selber schneller laufen kann. Zudem findet man im laufe des Spiels Gold, damit lassen sich die Einheiten verst√§rken oder man kauft sich Upgrades f√ºr die Gesundheit, Upgrades f√ºr die Riffs oder auch f√ºr die Map in der man die Schlachten austr√§gt. So k√∂nnen zum Beispiel die Dorfbewohner einem beim Kampf bei Seite stehen. Da kommt aber schon der erste Kritikpunkt: und zwar finde ich die Auswahl der Upgrades ziemlich durchschauber. Meiner Meinung nach w√§ren zum Beispiel mehr Riffs eine gute Abwechslung um vielleicht das Spielgeschehen etwas taktischer zu gestalten. Das ist aber noch kein Beinbruch, Bardbarian bietet trotzdem eine ordentliche Anzahl an Upgrades.
Was mich eher st√∂rt, ist dass man jedes mal auf der gleichen Map spielt und auch die Gegner sich nicht gro√ü ver√§ndern. Man k√∂nnte fast alle Gegnertypen mit einer Hand abz√§hlen. Das ist durchaus etwas mager, eine gr√∂√üere Anzahl an Gegner w√ºrde das Spielgeschehen durchaus interessanter machen. Das w√§re aber auch alles was mir im negativen Bereich einfallen w√ºrde. Man k√∂nnte vielleicht auch noch dazu sagen dass man Bardbarian nicht in einem run durchspielen kann. Man muss das Spiel mehrere male Anfangen um Upgrades zu kaufen. Ich habe f√ºr den normalen Modus 5 Stunden gebraucht. Ich w√ºrde hiermit auch einfach die Spielzeit bei 5-7 Stunden ansiedeln. Bei einem Preis von 5 euro absolut fair. Zudem bietet das Spiel noch einen Survival und einen Endless Modus, beide Modis sind sehr unterhaltsam und sind eine nette Dreingabe zur Hauptstory. 

[b]Fazit: Bardbarian vereint: Tower Defense und RPG perfekt. Sollte jedem 5 euro Wert sein. 82/100[/b]

[i]Anmerkung: Laut dem Entwickler wird das Spiel noch weiter entwickelt und wird folgende Funktionen beinhalten: Multiplayer, Steam Workshop Support, gr√∂√üere Auswahl an Gegner[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561197993618402', 'num_games_owned': 4295, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1188, 'last_played': 1589604453}
review:

Un tower defense combinado con estrategia y accion, que mezcla tan genialmente realizada, excelente musica (aunque despues de jugarlo por mas de 10 horas me d√≠ cuenta que era repetitiva). Puaj, el juego es tan divertido que los defectos se le perdonan.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983060770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 750, 'last_played': 1405958497}
review:
Simpaticissimo tower defense proveniente dal mercato touch/mobile (ma opportunamente "modificato" e migliorato per questa versione), Bardbarian √® una sorpresa: impegnativo, graficamente molto buono, con ottimi controlli, si gioca in modo veloce scegliendo via via sempre pi√π seguaci che dovremo adeguatamente pimpare con la musica (metal) del nostro liuto. Numerose le unit√†. le skills e le upgrades sbloccabili con i soldi guadagnati sul campo.
L'elemento centrale del gameplay sono i nostri spostamenti: il gruppo infatti ci seguir√† in modo credibile e lo schivare un colpo con il bardo non significher√† per forza schivarlo anche con gli altri del gruppo e gli spazi diventeranno presto molto stretti, pieni di proiettili persistenti (qui l'omaggio dei devs agli shumps √® palese).
Modalit√† storia discretamente longeva, survival e modalit√† "fugone".
Un piccolo gioco che funziona alla perfezione, immediato e metallaro.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025021719', 'num_games_owned': 559, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1404762779}
review: This one has some unique ideas, but I personally find the gameplay a bit too awkward. There's no way to attack anything directly (aside from expensive special attacks) and the only things that can routinely attack the enemies aren't directly controllabe by you. (They just sort of follow you around.) So it's hard to get them to dodge attacks, etc. Basically this game uses some good ideas, but the execution just isn't quite there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015015741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 854, 'last_played': 1405285066}
review: The game utilizes a simple mechanic but plays with it quite well.   It doesn't provide quite enough incentive to use the full range of units (there are quite a few with different abilities, but you'll probably specialize on a few favorites), but is an enjoyable romp nonetheless.  Pick it up the next time it goes on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055682145', 'num_games_owned': 563, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 355, 'last_played': 1405012906}
review:
Duracion del Juego con todos los Logros: 5.9h


El Juego esta entretendio, pero por lo que se es un juego de movil pasado a Steam, en el momento que hago el an√°lisis el juego cuenta con unos "poquitos" bugs, que te pueden llegar a fastidiar, aunque otros la verdad que han ayudado mucho jajaj.
-Se me rayo una vez y mis personajes no atacaban y pantallazo negro.
-A veces el botton "A" del mando deja de funcionar.
-Si usas una habilidad 2 veces superseguida, la consigues infinita (este es el bug bueno xD)

El Juego trata de pasar oleadas e ir matandolo, lo tipico, pero esta vez nosotros no hacemos anda directamente, es decir no podemos atacar, solo invocar criaturas y habilidades y dar vueltas, aunque suene un poco "co√±azo" no lo es para nada, los compa√±eros que te siguen atacan solos, pero tu tienes que moverte para esquivar los ataques del enemigo y poner a los tuyos a rango, mientras te ayudas de tus habilidades.

Cuentas con bastantes unidades, aunque muchas de ellas a mi gusto, son inservibles, las a√±aden por poner m√°s pero a la hora de usarlas en combate no son muy efectivas.

Yo lo compre en un Bundle y no me arrepiento, tiene 3 modos de juego, historia dividida en 4 partes "saves", un modo infinito en campo cerrado y una especie de "carrera" en la que solo corremos y cogemos oro mientras esquivamos ataques y enemigos.

La historia en modo "Insane" cuenta con un modo infinito a partir de la oleada 20, lo que lo hace muy dificil a partir de ah√≠ el juego, pero eso ya es ver hasta donde llega cada uno.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976001354', 'num_games_owned': 1671, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1405117471}
review:
--------------------
- Intro
--------------------

In this game you are put in control of Brad the local Hero. One day monsters attack Brad's village but when the local townspeople call upon his help Brad does not really feel in the mood for fighting.

So he picks up his custom guitar to play some tunes instead. With his massive tunes Brad can summon forth units of all sorts and sizes to protect him and fight in his place.

Will Brad be able to protect the towns Crystal and will he be able to fend of waves of foes come to destroy it?

--------------------
- About the Game
--------------------

To control Brad you can use either, keyboard or controller. Though a controller is highly recommended to get the best fun out of this game.

While standing still Brad plays his instrument which only then generates musical notes that can be used, like currency, to summon forth several units. 

Those units will follow Brad around and do the attacking instead. The units are anything from close to long range combat, each with unique attacks, strength and weaknesses.

At the beginning your maximum party size can only contain 3 summoned units, though this can be increased through upgrades you can purchase with gold coins that drop from enemies.

Musical notes are also used to allow the purchase of temporary buffs, such as increased speed, strength or raised defence.
Brad also has a special Stun skill that charges with each kill and is your out of Jail skill when things get hairy.

The game is progressing through waves of enemies which will try and destroy the town's Crystal. If the Crystal or you die the game ends and you will have to start from scratch again.

Though after several waves a Boss is encountered and upon defeating the boss you unlock a save point you can choose to continue from after you die.

Between deaths, you can use collected gold coins to upgrade the town, Brad himself, your units or purchase general perks.

Upgrades can be anything from stronger units to higher health, bigger party sizes (allowing more units to be summoned at any one time), increased musical note generation and much much more.

During each wave of enemies you must run around to get close to the enemies so your units can attack them. Be careful though as your units as well as yourself can get damaged and die.

If you die the game ends, if your units die you can re-summon another unit at the cost of Musical Notes which are not endless as they only generate when Brad stands still.

Sometimes musical notes are also dropped by enemies or can be given to you by supporting town folks you can purchase as perks in the upgrade store.

--------------------
- Summary
--------------------

The game is a lot of fun and the upgrade store has a lot to offer to make the game more interesting as you continue to play it adding great replay value. Death is expected in this game as it gives you then a chance to spend your hard-earned gold coins on upgrades and perks to support you to blast through more waves than before.

I definitely would recommend this game.

--------------------
- Known Bugs
--------------------
Brads special Stun skill is most of the time bugged and cannot be executed by keyboard or by controller.
The game is still fun and even without that skill very playable, just a little more challenging.

I don't know if it effects all users or only users with controllers or certain combination of things but either way the developers have replied in [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/269490/discussions/0/540739405184389960/]this thread[/url] that they are aware of it, had even released a fix in July but it still is bugged. (For me anyway).

I assume/hope another update is soon to follow.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031725194', 'num_games_owned': 1271, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1404996101}
review:
Bardbarian "is a mixture of Tower Defense, RPG & RTS with some 'Shmup and Snake elements". I have no clue where the RTS element is.

It's essentially a game about defending your town crystal from incoming waves of enemies. How do you defend it? You summon party members with different abilities, and you run around dodging bullets and buffing your party (you do not control your attacks, that's all done automatically).

When I saw this game, I thought it looked interesting enough to give it a go. The reviews were surprisingly positive, so... why not?

I'll just say that I was extremely disappointed with this game, and the reviews are unbelievable. I honestly don't know why people think this is a good game of PC! Here's a more lengthy analysis.


First off, [b]presentation[/b].
The [b]graphics[/b] look a bit average to me, but they're fine. What you see is what you get (from the screenshots). One problem with it, is that it's highly repetitive, even visually, since you have only one map for the campaign. And it doesn't really change its look. Other modes have different maps, but nothing beautiful or interesting. 
They're [b]fine[/b]. That's all I can say about it.

The [b]music[/b] was actually not bad. It's almost neo-classical metal, instrumental only. Unfortunately, there's only one song on the campaign. The song loops the entire time, which can (and does) get repetitive after listening to it hours on end. The song loops pretty seemlessly, so that's good (from what I could tell). It was just background music, didn't really add to the experience. 
There were no volume sliders either. Only music/sound-effects on/off.
[b]Very limited[/b] overall. A bit more effort and it could have been much more enjoyable, but playing the same track over and over and over... not good.

The [b]interface[/b] was fine. The mouse support works fine on the menus. I played the game with a Gamepad and it worked well as well, so good job on that. Unfortunately, the concept of an Options Meny seems to be very foreign to the developer. There's barely anything, which is really annoying. But hey, at least it had rebindable keys!
It's.. again, fine. Nothing noteworthy here, it's missing a bunch of options, but it didn't really prove to be a problem, in my experience.



So, how's [b]gameplay[/b]?
Well, it's a grindfest. Almost a waiting game...
As I said, you don't actually attack. So, your whole job is to summon party members, and run around the map, getting close enough for your party to attack. You can also boost the party with +Attack, +Speed, +Defense, or a special Stun ability. If your party member dies, you'll have to summon them again, at a cost. If you Bard dies, or your Crystal is destroyed, you lose. Simple enough. 

To summon units and use buffs, you'll need to gather "Notes". You gain a few over time, and you get some more from enemy drops, sometimes.
And that's pretty much it, as gameplay. 
Enemy variety was pretty good. They'll shoot at you, with some of them being faster, some firing multiple shots, in multiple directions, etc. It felt inspired by The Binding of Isaac (in a good way). That's not to say that the enemy variety is even remotely closer. Not at all. There are about 10 different enemies, and some of them are fairly similar. 

So, all you have to do is literally run around, for the most part. And it gets very old, very fast. It's clearly designed as an iOS game... And a lazy one.
It does have some bullet hell elements. And those could have saved the game! But, there's a huge problem with that. As I mentioned, you have units. These run around you. Which means that your hitbox is huge, and very inconsistent. You simply can't do those awesome dodges you would in a bullet hell. There's no way. 
There's an upgrade on the shop for the party to stick closer together, but it barely helps... Everytime you move, they'll stay a bit behind, which would be fine, but it provides nothing of worth! It simply inutilizes most of the dodging. Which means that you'll always play safe, run around, not feeling like a badass.
That's all the gameplay is. Running around. 
The Boss fights were significantly better, but still not very good. A few simple patterns, but they at least felt more refreshing.

The second part of this game, is the upgrading system. The game is structured with 4 times of the day, each with 5 levels (a Boss Fight in the 5th). Once you beat a Boss, you can't start from that point after you die, or you can go back to the beginning. This could have been fine, but it isn't.
The upgrades are absolutely necessary. It's literally impossible to make any progress without upgrading everything. And that's usually how games go, but this is different. Your progress is 95% affected by your upgrades. There's no skill involved. It's a question of either having enough damage, or not having it. Even if you're a good player, you'll simply be overun by enemies that will rush you crystal. Once you die, there you go upgrade some more, and then beat it easily. And that's the whole game. The upgrades aren't at all interesting. 
[b]They're just that, upgrades. More damage, more health, more speed, more money, more notes, etc.[/b]
This makes for a very, very stale game. You're always doing the same thing! Running around, collecting gold so that you can buy more upgrades, until you reach the end. There are no deep mechanics to learn or master, no strategy, no anything. 

The only glimpse of strategy, is choosing your units. You'll unlock different units throughout the game, with different abilities. There's a huge problem with it, though. First off, some of them are pretty much useless. They're not helpful at all, so there's no point in even existing. The other problem, is unit upgrades. 
You can upgrade them too (see it as levels, basically. higher level=better version of the unit, simply that). BUT, if you want to test a unit, and see if they're any good, you'll have to upgrade them to the same level that your other units are. Otherwise, you can't compare them very well, can you? But, to upgrade them, you'll waste gold, that you only want to use in a unit that you know will be useful. And this is where the system falls apart. 

To try the unit, you'll have to waste gold already, otherwise, there's no point, as they'll be incredibly underpowered. This makes it a waste of gold (which equals to a waste of time, as your play time is simply to collect enough gold to make progress!). [b]It's broken and pointless[/b]. This leads to a very limited cast of characters. I stuck around with most of the initial ones because of it. And I've done fine. Different characters could interact differently, but when the gameplay is literally just running around, it makes almost no difference! You don't play with the characters, they play themselves.



To its credit, there are 2 other game modes. One is just survival, in which you get a random unit spawn that you must collect, and sometimes food (healing). There are bosses, from time to time, and the enemies will try to kill you (no crystal this time).
The other one is an infinite runner mode, you a few stationary enemies (pretty much towers), and randomly spawned obstacles. Both of these modes unlock 2 cross-over characters, so you are encouraged to try them out.
The achievements were... meh. Barely anything to encourage you different (and interesting) character combinations, which is a really big miss. They're mostly for beating each Boss, unlocking characters, upgrades, etc. Nothing interesting. And that's unfortunate.


[b]Conclusion[/b]
This game is literally a waste of time. You'll collect gold to buy upgrades and progress in the game. You'll not learn how to master the mechanics the more you play. You won't feel any kind of rewarding sensation whenever you beat a Boss.

The game has potential, but ends up feeling like a lazy iOS game. You'll be entertained for 1-2 hours. Not more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020125851', 'num_games_owned': 15680, 'num_reviews': 840, 'playtime_forever': 111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1405028207}
review:
I had a pretty enjoyable experience with this.

It's a mix between a bullet-hell and a tower defense. You dodge enemy attacks, while recruiting "towers"  which will follow you around while shooting back at the enemy, the goal is to protect a building while at the same time not letting your Bard die. 

You can cast a small number of buffs which last a short while to boost your party.

People may disagree with me on this, but it reminds of a lot of Geometry Wars.

review: Ok Bardbarian is a cute and fun Tower Defence Game!! You play the Bard and you hire little minons to help you kill off waves of attackers.You yourself dont fight, you just run around and let them kill for you :) Its very RPGish there are upgrade you can buy for your minons and for yourself and the town to aid in your defence and attack. author: {'steamid': '76561198041543513', 'num_games_owned': 761, 'num_reviews': 213, 'playtime_forever': 696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1583391394}
review:
If you are into bullet-hell, mouse-manipulation, defense, and/or snake-style games, you should really enjoy this game.

I had played a similar style of game on the IOS, and it was super responsive because it was all through the touch screen. The app was very fleshed out.

This game is just as fleshed out, and I have enjoyed playing it thus far.

You play as a bard, so your player character does not actually attack. Instead, you summon support units (ex: archer, fighter, mage; party limit is initially 3 max) who follow you around, snake-style, and attack the closest enemies. In the beginning, you will notice that the party is a little spread out, and this is fixed by upgrading "body spray" in the store. The game is very charming and comical, the art and music is very good. 

Enemies spawn on the right side of the map and make their way toward your town gem on the left. Over time, you slowly gain "notes" that you use to summon units (you can select 3 from you unit pool to take along with you into the levels) and also to trigger buffs like enchanced damage, speed, or defense. 

The upgrading is pretty well fleshed out, as you can upgrade your units, your hero, and the town. For your units, it is basic overall upgrades like health and damage. There are also unlockable characters like Octodad and Super Meat Boy, which is a cute addition. Your hero can upgrade health, party size, party closeness (body spray), and other things. It is critical to upgrade the bard, as once he is dead, your round is over. 

Upgrading the town is crucial as well, as you can unlock things like a town pet who grabs gold for you (allowing you to effectively dodge more enemy projectiles and not worry about disappearing loot), a town drunk who periodically vomits, slowing any enemies that enter the bile radius. Later, you may unlock a high level barracks or college, which generates extra free units to help you in defense of the town.

The game is really, really fun if you like this style of gameplay, and you can easily spend time playing this if you enjoy upgrading to completion.

The controls are very responsive, you can easily play with just the mouse, but I recommend you either use the keyboard (WASD) to move + mouse to trigger skills, or to use the mouse to move and the keyboard hotkeys to summon units and trigger skills. The tutorial is short, skippable, and very helpful. Learning curve is minimal, however, the game is suprisingly difficult in thr beginning - I had thought I was fighting the boss, but it was only the "pre-boss" (indicated by a skull on the minimap. The real bosses come when you move onto a red (vs. blue) square on the minimap. 

Needless to say, I got served very hard.

Give it a try, definitely recommend.
